The Riley Oil Company is a family business that's lasted for decades. And they plan to keep it going for decades more. (Source: WAVE 3 News)
At the Riley Oil Company, they pump your gas, wash your windshield and check your oil -- for free. (Source: WAVE 3 News)
Paoli, Indiana has one of the last full service gas stations operating in the area. (Source: WAVE 3 News)
PAOLI, IN (WAVE) - Like many American towns, Paoli has evolved with the times.
The changing of the decades show in the decrepit drive-in movie theater. Something that you now just drive by.
However, there's one thing in Paoli that hasn't changed one bit. A full service gas station stands right next to the downtown roundabout.
"We pump the gas for you, wash your windshields, and they get pretty happy about that," Daniel McCabe said.
>> More Community news on wave3.com
McCabe is a newbie at Riley Oil Company. He said he started back in August after he lost his other job. He also said it was pretty cool knowing that he is one of the few who hold the position of gas pump assistant.
Customers who come by said it's a treat from the past.
"You don't necessarily want to get out and pump your own gas and here you can stay in your car and just do it that way," Loretta Brown said.
McCabe said he especially enjoys the small talk, getting to know residents of Paoli. Owners Jo Ann and Jeff Riley said that's their favorite part too.
"You get out there and you talk to so many people," Jo Ann Riley said. "Everybody has a story and every story is different."
Riley said the royal treatment has been around for decades.
"It started in 1971," Riley said. "Glendon Riley, which is my husband's father -- he opened it."
Since then, not once did the business stray from the most important thing: family. It's a Riley empire, honestly.
"Me, Troy, Eric, dad, Jodie, Jackie, so we have six?" Jeff Riley said, counting the family members on his fingers. "Six Riley's that work here."
Jo Ann explained the family continues to grow.
MORE FROM WAVE3.COM
+ WAVE Country is #MarshallStrong
+ Residents at historic home digging in as museum looks to expand
+ 2018 KDF Pegasus Pins unveiled
"There are already great-grandbabies being born so I imagine it will be in the family for a long time," Jo Ann said. She added that the service they provide is a dedication to their customers.
"A lot of places will say they'll pump it for a penny more," Jo Ann said. "We're not going to charge you a penny more."
The miles have meaning alright. At Riley's a gallon takes you through generations.
"It's just family everywhere, you know it's just family," Riley said. "We just, I think we have gas running through our veins instead of blood sometimes."
Copyright 2018 WAVE 3 News. All rights reserved.

Company, the commitment to quality and community has been the cornerstone of their operations. Founded in the 1970s, the company has grown from a small local distributor to a key player in the regional fuel market. The current owner, Sarah Riley, emphasizes the importance of family values in their business model. "We treat our customers like family," she said. "It's not just about selling fuel; it's about building relationships."

In recent years, Riley Oil has also made strides in sustainability, investing in cleaner fuel options and exploring renewable energy sources. This forward-thinking approach has not only attracted environmentally conscious consumers but has also positioned the company as a leader in the industry.

As they look to the future, the Rileys are focused on expanding their services while maintaining their commitment to the community. They plan to launch a new loyalty program and support local initiatives, ensuring that the company remains a vital part of the community for generations to come.

She's openly shared pictures of the stretch marks covering her thighs, and now Chrissy Teigen is lifting the lid on stretch marks during pregnancy and what she does to avoid them.
The 32-year-old who is mom to two-year-old Luna is due to give birth to her second child, a son, in June.
And speaking to Refinery29, the searingly honest author and model explained that as she's from 'a real stretch mark-prone family', she's had stretch marks for years.
Honest: Model and author Chrissy Teigen, 32, has opened up about the products she uses during pregnancy to avoid stretch marks
Go-tos: Chrissy's routine includes Aquaphor, $4.99, Lumi√®re Concentrate, $85.95, and coconut oil
Lucky: Mom to two-year-old Luna and due to give birth to her second child, a son, in June, Chrissy admitted to Refinery29 that her belly is the one place she doesn't get marks
'I had stretch marks way before the baby. Mine went to my inner thighs for some reason ‚Äî my thighs just got really angry one year.'
Referencing an Instagram post from August 2015 where her stretch marks on her thighs could clearly be seen, she added that she didn't post her 'stretchies for the praise'.
'I post[ed] it because [of] the wine also I like the pattern and they're so soft.'
However that doesn't mean she's complacent when it comes to preventing them on her belly during pregnancy and shared that for her, it's all about prevention.
'Sometimes, we only take care of our skin when we see a breakout happening, but with stretch marks, it's all about prevention,' she said.
And she's a big fan of getting the whole family involved: 'I'm big now, so it's hard for me to bend over. John helps me a lot with everything at the end of the night. Luna loves helping out.
'It's exhausting to do this 10-15 minute session of lubing up your belly and body, with all these different layers, especially when you're like, "I don't even have a stretch mark yet!"'
Admitting that as she has naturally dry skin, Chrissy uses a combination of products to keep her skin soft, smooth and stretch mark free, and uses budget drugstore brand Aquaphor on her elbows, along with coconut oil all over her body.
Prep: However, she spends 10-15 minutes per night applying products to her belly to prevent any scarring and says prepping the skin before any stretching occurs is key
Family affair: Chrissy also shared that she gets her husband John Legend and daughter Luna also help out every night
Stretchies say hi: Chrissy has been open about her battle with stretch marks in the past and posted this candid shot of her stretch mark covered thighs in April 2015
However, her favorite products come from high-end skincare brand Lumi√®re de Vie because - as she candidly confessed during the interview - she gets it for free.
'Honestly, a lot of it comes from Lumi√®re because I worked with them and they send it to me,' she explained.
'That's one of the only beauty campaigns I did where it was like, I would do this for products. I don't need money, I don't need anything ‚Äî Lumi√®re is just such an incredible product.'
She uses the brand's concentration on her belly, 'especially around the sides because you never know where stretch marks are going to pop up.'
'The only place I don't have stretch marks on my body is my belly. The other places that have them are from regular wear and tear of my body,' she added.
However, Chrissy also shared that she's never seen a woman without stretch marks, and detailed how every model she's worked with has had at least one.
'I've worked with every supermodel in the world. I'm lucky to know that the most incredibly beautiful women all have stretch marks and all have the butt dimples. It really is our common bond.'

...them. In a recent interview, Teigen revealed that she has embraced her body‚Äôs changes throughout her pregnancies, emphasizing the importance of self-acceptance. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve learned to love my stretch marks as part of my journey,‚Äù she said. 

To help manage the appearance of stretch marks, Teigen shared her skincare routine, which includes moisturizing with rich creams and oils. She swears by products that contain cocoa butter and hyaluronic acid, claiming they keep her skin hydrated and elastic. 

Teigen also highlighted the role of genetics in skin elasticity, noting that some women may be more prone to stretch marks than others. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all about being kind to yourself and understanding that your body is doing something incredible,‚Äù she added. 

Her candidness has resonated with many, encouraging others to embrace their bodies and the changes that come with motherhood. Teigen‚Äôs message is clear: beauty comes in all forms, and self-love is essential.

OCEANSIDE ‚Äî Lifeguard David Wilson was honored this week for a heroic water rescue that saved a life.
The rescue occurred July 17, 2016. Wilson was on unit patrol at Harbor Beach tower 14 along with veteran lifeguard Mike Wagner.
‚ÄúIt was a pretty busy day,‚Äù Wilson said.
He began his day instructing students in the Junior Lifeguard Program. He then continued to put in patrol hours due to sizable summer crowds and rough seas.
Earlier that afternoon he was part of several land and sea rescues, including getting a child out of a locked sweltering car.
Then came a distress call about a solo jet skier crashed on the jetty at the mouth of the harbor. The location of the accident is nicknamed the ‚Äúdevil‚Äôs triangle‚Äù due to the dangers the rock jetty poses.
Wilson responded and found the man thrown off the jet ski, semiconscious, wedged between two boulders and unable to free himself. He attempted to free the man as consistent sets of pounding waves hit him and the victim.
While Wilson aided the victim a city harbor officer pulled up in a patrol boat and lent a hand in the difficult rescue. The two were able to put a lifejacket under the victim‚Äôs head as a buoy.
To set the man free, Wilson needed to dive underwater and release the victim‚Äôs legs. Eventually the pair dislodged the man, but not without getting knocked down by waves and enduring some major scrapes from the surrounding rocks, which Wilson described as a cheese grater.
‚ÄúIt seemed forever, we got beat up pretty well, yelling ‚Äòbrace‚Äô between waves,‚Äù Wilson said.
A city firefighter arrived and the three pulled the victim from the rocks between sets of waves, up onto a stretcher and to an awaiting air ambulance. Due to HIPPA privacy laws the name of the victim has not been released.
‚ÄúNo doubt that without his iron effort, knowledge and skill in the ocean environment, a life would have been lost,‚Äù Capt. Bill Curtis, Oceanside Fire Department Lifeguard Division, said.
‚ÄúDavid knowingly placed himself in harm‚Äôs way with one goal and an incredible outcome.‚Äù
For most the work day would end there, but Wilson showered off his cut leg and returned to duty to help with an issued code five alert. That afternoon he pulled 20 people from the harbor‚Äôs choppy waters.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one of the crazier situations I‚Äôve been in,‚Äù Wilson said.
Code five rescue operations involved every lifeguard on duty. Wilson said to aid multiple people in distress his partner paddled out on a rescue board, directed a group of five people to hold on and Wilson swam two of them at a time into shore.
‚ÄúIt was a good day with a positive outcome,‚Äù Wilson said.
Despite his long day and injuries Wilson was at the Junior Lifeguard Program the following morning instructing potential future guards.
The recognition ceremony for his heroism took place in Sacramento on Sept. 25. Out of 21 applicants Wilson was the only one to receive the prestigious Governor‚Äôs Public Safety Medal of Valor this year.
Wilson grew up in Oceanside and has served as a city lifeguard since 2012. He just completed criminal justice studies and plans to pursue a career as a State Beach peace officer ranger/lifeguard.
He said his career path was inspired by fellow Oceanside lifeguards whose rescues have become legend.
‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt a lot of people in this profession who get recognized for their amazing feats,‚Äù Wilson said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm beyond blessed being able to do this.‚Äù
Last year Oceanside beaches saw more than 4 million visitors. Lifeguards prevented more than 82,000 accidents and performed in excess of 3,000 water rescues.

...Oceanside Beach when he noticed a commotion in the water. A swimmer had been caught in a rip current and was struggling to stay afloat. Without hesitation, Wilson sprang into action, diving into the turbulent waves. He swam against the current, reaching the distressed swimmer just in time. With his training and experience, Wilson was able to secure the swimmer and guide them back to safety.

The swimmer, a local resident, expressed immense gratitude for Wilson's quick response and bravery. "I truly believe he saved my life," they said during the ceremony where Wilson was recognized. The Oceanside Lifeguard Association presented him with a commendation for his courage and dedication to public safety. 

City officials praised Wilson's actions, highlighting the importance of lifeguards in ensuring beachgoers' safety. "David exemplifies the spirit of our community and the commitment of our lifeguards," said the mayor during the award presentation.

The Great Southern Storm have named an initial colts squad of 45 players under a new coach as they prepare for the Great Southern Colts Carnival in Kulin next month.
The initial squad will have two training sessions in the lead-up to the final travelling team being selected and will feature a new-look coaching panel, with Glynn Verbruggen taking over from long-standing mentor Phil Gilbert.
Gilbert, a former AFL player with Melbourne and Fremantle, was head coach of the Storm for seven of the past eight years and has moved to Perth. Verbruggen won the Sean Plaisted Medal as the leading goal kicker in the Great Southern Football League in 2008 and has senior coaching experience with Northampton in the Great Northern Football League.
Recently Verbruggen has been in charge of the Claremont 15s development squad and was excited by the challenge of being announced as the Storm‚Äôs head figure.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm really excited to take over as the senior Storm coach,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve stayed away from coaching senior football down here for this chance and the aim was to take over from Phil when he left.
‚ÄúThe opportunity has come up and I‚Äôm really keen to get in and help with the talented kids from the region.‚Äù
A strong squad has been named this week featuring a host of young players who are regulars at league level, while State 16 squad members Heath Spinks and Jacob Blight have also been included.
Squad members Fraser Eaton, Bryce Blaszkow, Tom Wolfe, Taj Williams, Lachy O‚ÄôShea, Ted Batchelor, Hayden Parker and Aidin Williss have already played State Country colts this season.
North Albany has the biggest representation with 12 members, Railways has eight while Albany and Royals each have seven players named.
‚ÄúIt will be good to get a look at all the talented kids over two sessions and over the next two rounds of local footy,‚Äù Verbruggen said.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a really even squad with a lot of younger age kids and we definitely will be very competitive at Kulin.‚Äù
The squad will train at Railways on June 4 and 11, from 5.30pm.
Great Southern Storm colts squad
Jake Abbott, Zainel Bin Busu, Bryce Blaszkow, Fraser Eaton, Kieran Gowdie, Marcus Mellon, Callum Redshaw (Albany) Codey Baxter, Richard Cullinan, Rex Ogier, Liam Park, Griffin Roy (Denmark-Walpole) Nitan Benavides, Devin Cooper, Rhys Hogg, Jacob Skinner, Aidin Williss (Mt Barker) Ted Batchelor, Aden Castlehow, Jake Castlehow, Jeff Fitzpatrick, Kohen Lemin, Ned McSweeney, Lachy O‚ÄôShea, Alex Pearce, Braden Retallack, Connor Spinks, Heath Spinks, Taj Williams (North Albany) Joe Alvin, Jacob Blight, Aidan Dallimore, Hayden Davies, Nelson Kent, Jack Steel, Jayden Scott, Tom Wolfe (Railways) Regan Askevold, Rivah Bocian, Jaike Dale, Nic Finlay, Jaxon Nottle, Ben Watson, Brandon Woods (Royals)

The squad features a mix of promising young talent and experienced players, showcasing the depth of the region's footballing prowess. Coach Jamie Thompson expressed his excitement about the upcoming carnival, emphasizing the importance of teamwork and development. "This is a fantastic opportunity for these young athletes to showcase their skills and gain valuable experience," Thompson said. 

Among the standout selections are several players who have excelled in local leagues, including standout forward Liam Carter and dynamic midfielder Sarah Jenkins. The team will undergo a rigorous training schedule leading up to the carnival, focusing on building cohesion and refining their strategies. 

The Great Southern Colts Carnival is set to attract scouts and fans alike, providing a platform for these young players to shine. The squad will be trimmed down closer to the event, but for now, the focus remains on preparation and fostering a competitive spirit within the group.

She seemed to let slip that she was expecting a baby boy during an appearance on RTE One's Cutting Edge earlier this month, before trying to cover it up.
But Vogue Williams confirmed the worst-kept secret in the world on Instagram stories on Tuesday when she referred to the baby as 'he'.
She looked incredible posing in a sexy black swimsuit and joked that you can only see the bump from the side.
Stunning: Pregnant Vogue Williams showed off her blossoming bump in a black one-piece as she enjoyed some time in Hong Kong on Tuesday
The big reveal: She confirmed that she is in fact expecting a boy as she referred to her baby as 'he' - she did it once before on a TV show earlier this month but tried to backtrack
Posing in a Hong Kong bathroom in the swimsuit which had cut-out sections at the side, the model wrote: 'Wearing my girl @melissaodabash.'
She wrote on a picture of herself from the side, she added the caption: 'Don't worry, he's still here,' next to a cry-face emoji.
Vogue's soon-to-be sister-in-law Pippa Middleton is said to be expecting her first child at the same time as her.
And on Sunday, she slipped into a bikini in the garden just hours after claims that another Matthews baby was on the way.
That morning, it was reported that James Matthews, the older brother of Vogue's fiance Spencer, was 'overjoyed' to be expecting his first child with wife Pippa, who happens to be the Duchess of Cambridge's little sister.
Bumping along: Vogue posted another side profile bump shot on Sunday, after lashing out at claims she edited her baby bump in a front on shot last week
Currently bumping along nicely with her own pregnancy, Vogue shared a bump picture as she enjoyed the London sunshine.
The Irish model looked glorious in a little golden bandeau bikini, exposing her pregnancy shape as she turned to one side and posed while standing on a garden bench with her dog.
She wrote beside it: 'I should be packing but it‚Äôs sooooo sunny and I have a new bikini and sunglasses!'
Spencer's gorgeous bride-to-be also wrote 'I love my bump' beside the picture as she caught some rays.
Loved-up: Vogue Williams and Spencer Matthews bid farewell to their 'magical' Grecian baby-moon at Domes Noruz Chania in Crete as they posted a sweet holiday snap on Thursday
Expecting? On Sunday, it was reported that Spencer's brother James Matthews (left) is expecting his first child with wife Pippa Middleton (right, on their wedding day, last May)
Vogue posted side profile shot after being forced to deny she photoshopped her baby bump in a front-on shot last week.
The Irish beauty lashed out at trolls, explaining how two angles looked so different to one another.
'These photos were taken within half an hour of each other,' she explained. 'Front on no bump, side profile POW there he is! So glad my bump has finally popped.
'I never alter my body in any pictures, if you can‚Äôt see my bump it‚Äôs just because of the angle although I may only take side profile shots from now on!'
B UT Spencer and Vogue have just got back from a glorious babymoon in Crete.
Bidding farewell to the holiday spot, they posted a loved-up holiday snap via Instagram on Thursday morning.
The happy couple looked besotted in the sunset snap, which both uploaded just hours after Vogue took to social media to slam claims she had digitally altered pictures of her baby bump.
Vogue, 32, and Spencer, 28, put on a cosy display as they posed in front of the Greek sunset, with the Irish TV presenter shielding her growing bump in a flowing yellow maxi dress.
Daddy-to-be Spencer captioned his post: 'Last night was magical... We are FAMILY... Can the Little one hurry up already @voguewilliams?'
Meanwhile Vogue wrote: 'The end of our amazing holiday... there is nobody I would rather be with @spencermatthews.'
Bumping along: The side profile shot comes days after the Irish TV presenter, 32, took to social media to slam claims she had digitally altered pictures of her baby bump
Gorgeous: Vogue took to Instagram on Wednesday to share a skimpy bikini snap as she hit back at claims she edits her social media snaps
The couple's sun-soaked getaway came after Spencer and James's multi-millionaire father David Matthews was arrested and charged with sexual assault by French Police.
The 74-year-old was released on bail last month pending further investigation, and Spencer it yet to comment publicly on the news.
A spokesperson for the family said: 'David Matthews categorically denies the allegation and unequivocally contests the untrue and scandalous accusation.'

the revelation has sparked a flurry of excitement among fans and followers. The host, who was discussing various topics, inadvertently mentioned "he" when referring to the baby, prompting speculation about the gender of her child. Although she quickly attempted to backtrack, the slip has only fueled interest in her pregnancy journey.

Social media platforms erupted with congratulatory messages and theories about potential names for the baby boy. Fans have been eagerly awaiting updates, and this latest hint has only intensified their curiosity. 

In the days following the appearance, the star has remained tight-lipped about further details, choosing instead to focus on her upcoming projects. However, insiders suggest that she is over the moon about the impending arrival and is preparing for motherhood with great enthusiasm. As the due date approaches, many are left wondering if she will share more about her pregnancy or keep the details under wraps until the big day arrives.

By partnering together to promote the adoption of cybersecurity best practices, the NTSC and CSA will aim to improve vendor security. Specifically, the two organizations will help standardize and improve cloud security vendor reviews by promoting and strengthening the CSA's Security, Trust & Assurance Registry (STAR) and related CSA tools as recommended practices for cloud security and vendor evaluations.
"We are excited to partner with the NTSC to make common cause toward raising the bar for cloud computing security and all new emerging technologies," said Jim Reavis, CEO of Cloud Security Alliance. "CSA STAR is the world's largest cloud computing assurance program which, combined with NTSC's focus on CISO advocacy, will help accelerate trust of the cloud while preventing key stakeholders from reinventing the wheel."
The NTSC and CSA are seeking to streamline the vendor security review process; reduce time, energy, and effort by encouraging best practices for vendors; and offer benefits to vendors who abide by this process and best practices. Together, the organizations will collaborate on a STAR-based questionnaire that maps to the most used compliance frameworks. A joint whitepaper will then provide information about this program, how CISOs can incorporate this program into their companies, and how vendors would incorporate the program when planning to work with organizations.
"The information security industry needs to evolve the way it assesses and improves cloud vendor security," said Patrick Gaul, Executive Director of the NTSC. "CISOs don't have the same kind of transparency with third party cloud security vendors as they do with their own network systems. I'm excited that the preeminent CISO and cloud security auditing associations are partnering together, and we look forward to promoting a more rigorous way to help CISOs vet cloud security vendors based on CSA's successful STAR program."
In addition to partnering on a cloud security vetting program, the CSA and the NTSC will also participate in each other's events, discuss industry issues in working groups, and collaborate on research involving cloud security. The NTSC encourages dialogue about cybersecurity issues, laws, and regulations through advocacy engagement with congressional members, regional CISO policy roundtables, and an annual DC Fly-In as part of its National CISO Policy Conference. The CSA holds many conferences, summits, events, and forums around the world to promote the use of best practices for providing security assurance within cloud computing.
About Cloud Security Alliance
The Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) is the world's leading organization dedicated to defining and raising awareness of best practices to help ensure a secure cloud computing environment. CSA harnesses the subject matter expertise of industry practitioners, associations, governments, and its corporate and individual members to offer cloud security-specific research, education, certification, events and products. CSA's activities, knowledge and extensive network benefit the entire community impacted by cloud ‚Äî from providers and customers, to governments, entrepreneurs and the assurance industry ‚Äî and provide a forum through which diverse parties can work together to create and maintain a trusted cloud ecosystem.
About the National Technology Security Coalition (NTSC)
The National Technology Security Coalition (NTSC) is a non-profit, on-partisan organization that serves as the preeminent advocacy voice for Chief Information Security Officers (CISOs) across the nation. Through dialogue, education, and government relations, we unite both public and private sector stakeholders around policies that improve national cybersecurity standards and awareness.
Twitter @NTSC_CISO

http://www.cloudsecurityalliance.org

...security protocols across various industries, ensuring that vendors adhere to a unified set of guidelines. This collaboration will focus on developing comprehensive training programs and resources that equip organizations with the necessary tools to enhance their cybersecurity measures. 

The NTSC (National Technology Security Council) and CSA (Cloud Security Alliance) will also work on creating a framework for assessing vendor security, which will include regular audits and compliance checks. By establishing these standards, the organizations aim to reduce vulnerabilities and foster a culture of security awareness among vendors and their clients.

In addition, the partnership will facilitate knowledge sharing through workshops, webinars, and industry conferences, allowing stakeholders to stay informed about the latest threats and mitigation strategies. This initiative is expected to not only bolster individual vendor security but also contribute to a more resilient supply chain, ultimately benefiting consumers and businesses alike in an increasingly digital landscape.

By LAURIE KELLMAN
WASHINGTON ‚Äî The nation‚Äôs political leaders bowed their heads for a solemn salute Wednesday to the Rev. Billy Graham in the soaring Capitol Rotunda, paying tribute to a man who ministered to presidents and other Americans of both parties.
‚ÄúHere lies America‚Äôs pastor,‚Äù said House Speaker Paul Ryan, gesturing to Graham‚Äôs casket under the eye of the dome, surrounded by family, friends, lawmakers and a ring of paintings of the nation‚Äôs founders. ‚ÄúHe ministered to all walks, from some of the greats whose statues line this hall_Eisenhower, King, Ford, and Reagan_to the everyday citizens lining up today to pay their respects.‚Äù
President Donald Trump said his father was an admirer of Graham‚Äôs and that the ‚Äúlegendary‚Äù American figure deserved to be recognized in the place ‚Äúwhere the memory of the American people is enshrined.‚Äù
Graham‚Äôs influence stretched far beyond the city where he counseled lawmakers to a global flock over the better part of seven decades.
‚ÄúThe man we recognize today shared the Gospel with more people, face-to-face, than anyone else in history,‚Äù said Sen. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.
As the leaders stood by the casket, Trump reached out to touch the bare wood and Ryan bowed his head.
Graham died a week earlier at age 99. Some 30 family members are accompanying Graham‚Äôs casket to Washington, where he befriended presidents of both parties and counseled others over seven decades. Graham‚Äôs son, Franklin, tweeted a photo Wednesday of family members loading the casket onto a jet emblazoned with ‚ÄúSamaritan‚Äôs Purse,‚Äù the name of a Christian relief charity that he chairs.
Graham is lying in honor before a funeral Friday near his home in Charlotte, North Carolina. The Rotunda entrances were draped with black fabric, and Graham‚Äôs casket rested on a black-draped catafalque beneath the soaring ceiling and its painting, the ‚ÄúApotheosis of Washington.‚Äù
Though he met every president since Harry Truman and counseled most, Graham grew wary of politics after Watergate. He was closest to Richard Nixon but later said he felt used by him.
Nonetheless, Graham ministered to other presidents until his health began to fail about 10 years ago.
Former President Bill Clinton recalled seeing one of Graham‚Äôs crusades as a child, a profound experience that became more amazing over his life. Graham counseled him as Arkansas governor, and later as president in the White House itself.
‚ÄúIn that little room, he was the same person I saw when I was 11 on that football field,‚Äù Clinton said Tuesday after viewing the casket at Graham‚Äôs home.
Former President George W. Bush and his wife, Laura, also visited Graham‚Äôs home on Tuesday.
In Washington, Ryan said there had been no doubt that Graham would receive the honor of a public viewing in the Rotunda. He told reporters that almost immediately upon hearing of Graham‚Äôs death he, Trump, McConnell and Rep. Patrick McHenry, who represents the Graham family‚Äôs district, agreed it would happen.
Graham shares the honor with 11 presidents and other distinguished Americans, starting with Sen. Henry Clay of Kentucky in 1852 and, most recently, Sen. Daniel Inouye of Hawaii in 2012, according to the House and the Architect of the Capitol.
Graham is only the fourth private person to lie in honor since 1998. The others are two U.S. Capitol Police officers who died in the line of duty in 1998 and civil rights hero Rosa Parks in 2005.
Trump met Graham at the pastor‚Äôs 95th birthday party in 2013, but is closer to Franklin Graham Jr.
On Friday, Trump was to attend Graham‚Äôs funeral near his library in Charlotte, North Carolina. Former Presidents Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush will not be there, meaning no former presidents will attend the funeral.
Follow Kellman at http://www.twitter.com/APLaurieKellman

...the evangelical icon who passed away at the age of 99. Graham, known for his powerful sermons and ability to connect with millions, was honored in a ceremony that drew lawmakers from both sides of the aisle, reflecting his impact on American society and politics. 

House Speaker Paul Ryan praised Graham as a "spiritual adviser to presidents" and a man who "brought hope to millions." Senators and representatives shared personal anecdotes, recalling how Graham's messages of faith and love transcended political divides. 

The service featured readings from scripture and musical tributes, including hymns that Graham often used in his crusades. His casket, draped in a simple American flag, was surrounded by floral arrangements, symbolizing the respect he garnered throughout his life. 

As the nation remembers Graham's legacy, many reflect on his commitment to spreading a message of unity and compassion in a time of increasing division.

A Twitter user's list of Bible verses took an unexpected turn when it became a meme.
It all started when Twitter user @brianab1188 tweeted a list of Bible verses for troubling moods, from feeling lonely to needing direction.
SEE ALSO: A floating dumpster became the most relatable meme

Weak - Psalm 18:1-29
Lonely - Psalm 23
Sinned - Psalm 51
Worried - Matthew 8:18-31

Unhappy - Colossians 3:12-17
In danger - Psalm 91

Need Direction - Psalm 73:21-26 ‚Äî Bri (@brianab1188) May 23, 2018
With over 243,000 likes and 121,000 comments, it's clear that her list of verses resonated with thousands of people.
Since it went viral though, @brianab1188's had a different impact than she probably expected. People started tweeting their list of songs to listen to in times of anxiety and stress ‚Äî who wouldn't want to listen to "Come On Eileen" when they need courage?

Need Courage - Come on Eil- https://t.co/P3x4y7Dfv1 ‚Äî urs üêù (@bubblegumtrixie) May 27, 2018

...encouragement and inspiration. The tweet quickly gained traction, with users sharing their own favorite verses and adding humorous commentary. What began as a heartfelt message transformed into a lighthearted meme, with users creatively pairing the verses with relatable life situations and funny images.

One popular response featured a verse about patience alongside a picture of a cat waiting for its food, while another paired a verse on love with a clip from a romantic comedy. The hashtag #BibleVerseMeme began trending, as more users joined in on the fun, showcasing their wit and creativity.

Despite the playful nature of the memes, many participants expressed appreciation for the original verses, highlighting how humor can be a bridge to deeper conversations about faith. The unexpected twist on a simple tweet has sparked a broader dialogue about the relevance of scripture in everyday life, proving that even sacred texts can inspire laughter and connection in the digital age.

Following Sunday‚Äôs mass shooting in Las Vegas, many country musicians and fans have been wondering about guns and safety ‚Äì about how far the government should act and whether people can still feel safe going to concerts.
But country legend Charlie Daniels has a different take on it.
‚ÄúI feel like this is an anomaly,‚Äù said the Wilmington native, calling Friday from a tour stop in New Mexico. ‚ÄúI think this guy was a nut, a problem waiting to happen. I think if we let ourselves be made afraid of those kinds of things, we‚Äôre done and the bad guys have won.‚Äù
Country superstar Jason Aldean was performing at the Route 91 Harvest festival in Las Vegas Oct. 1, the last day of a three-day event, when a gunman opened fire from a nearby hotel room with high-powered weapons. Fifty-eight people were killed and more than 500 were injured.
That‚Äôs led to a vigorous debate about firearms and gun-control laws, particularly country music‚Äôs responsibility in it. The National Rifle Association has close ties with the country music industry through N.R.A. Country, which says on its website that it‚Äôs ‚Äúpowered by pride, love of country, respect for the military and our responsibility to protect our great American lifestyle.‚Äù

Eric Church tearfully sings for fan who died in Las Vegas shooting Eric Church performed for his fans at the Las Vegas country music festival two nights before the bullets flew, killing 58 and wounding hundreds. He sang a song Monday night at the Grand Ole Opry that he wrote for one of those fans, one of the 58 who died. Eric Church tearfully sings for fan who died in Las Vegas shooting Eric Church performed for his fans at the Las Vegas country music festival two nights before the bullets flew, killing 58 and wounding hundreds. He sang a song Monday night at the Grand Ole Opry that he wrote for one of those fans, one of the 58 who died. Courtesy of Taylor Hendrix
Rosanne Cash, a musician, gun control activist and daughter of the late Johnny Cash, penned a New York Times essay this week headlined, ‚ÄúCountry Musicians, Stand Up to the N.R.A.‚Äù
Daniels hadn‚Äôt read Cash‚Äôs essay, but said, ‚ÄúThings happen, you know.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not much of a ‚ÄòWhat if?‚Äô guy,‚Äù he said. ‚Äú‚ÄòWhat if a piece of an airplane falls on you out of the sky?‚Äô Well, that‚Äôs probably not gonna happen. Same way with these things. You can‚Äôt worry about it.‚Äù
Daniels said he agrees with the National Rifle Association‚Äôs support of regulations on ‚Äúbump stock‚Äù devices that convert semi-automatic weapons to automatic weapons. But he doesn‚Äôt agree with wider calls for stricter gun laws.
‚ÄúI just wish people who actually knew something about guns would say something,‚Äù Daniels said. ‚ÄúSome of the politicians talking about gun control don‚Äôt know what the hell they‚Äôre talking about. A lot of things they call assault rifles are just deer rifles with a bigger magazine.
‚ÄúIf you want to see what the gun control that politicians talk about would do, look at Chicago,‚Äù Daniels added. ‚ÄúChicago has some of the strictest laws in the country and it‚Äôs a damn slaughterhouse. That‚Äôs what would happen in America if the kind of gun-control laws (Sen.) Chuck Schumer and (Rep.) Nancy Pelosi want were to take place. You would leave people defenseless.‚Äù
Daniels will headline an Oct. 21 show at Cary‚Äôs Booth Amphitheatre.

...should have the right to bear arms in the wake of such tragedies. The shooting, which left dozens injured and several dead, has reignited the debate over gun control in America. Many artists took to social media to express their condolences and call for change, with some advocating for stricter regulations on firearm sales and ownership.

In the days following the incident, several country music stars participated in discussions about mental health and the need for comprehensive background checks. Fans at concerts have also voiced their concerns, with some calling for venues to implement enhanced security measures to ensure safety during live performances.

As the country grapples with the aftermath of the shooting, the conversation around guns and safety continues to evolve. Musicians and fans alike are left to ponder the balance between personal freedoms and the need for a safer environment, both on and off the stage.

Britain‚Äôs red carpet night for the stars of the silver screen took place last night at London‚Äôs Royal Albert Hall with the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in attendance at the 70th edition of the BAFTAs. This was the first time the royal couple have been together on this red carpet, turning up the heat on the jewellery front, and Kate didn‚Äôt disappoint. Confirming the red-carpet trend, Kate chose large earrings over a statement necklace worn with her off-the shoulder floral print gown by Alexander McQueen.
The Duchess of Cambridge‚Äôs large chandelier earrings have us all guessing. According to the Daily Mail, Kensington Palace will not comment on whether they were a loan or from the Duchess‚Äô own jewellery box, but they have had previous outings. Our hunch is that the jewels are by a British designer and that the pink stones are morganites ‚Äì the Duchess has shown a preference for pastel-coloured gems ‚Äì surrounded by old-cut diamonds.
These classic yet so very Kate earrings were possibly commissioned by the Duchess herself, but no jeweller worth her commission would dare to spill the beans, so we will just have to keep guessing. The articulated diamond bracelet looks like it might be an Art Deco jewel from the Queen‚Äôs personal collection. She was, of course, wearing her sapphire engagement ring.
Beyond the excitement caused by the Duchess of Cambridge, bold embroidered floral motifs on gowns were the main couture trend, dominated by Alexander McQueen, Gucci, Dior and Tom Ford. With embellished dresses a strong style statement, glamorous earrings to complement the decorative flourishes as opposed to showstopper necklaces marked the night.
After the Duchess of Cambridge, Emily Blunt was the most polished example of how to pair an elaborate gown with jewels. She wore her Alexander McQueen gown with Lorraine Schwartz jewels. In her lobes were a pair of 50-carat blue sapphire earrings and on her finger, a playful, lifesize, lifelike dragonfly ring that looked as if it had just fluttered out from the Oriental garden embroidered on her dress.
Bulgari picked a winner as Viola Davis, below, raised her prize for Best Supporting Actress wearing a diamond Serpenti bracelet coiling up her arm and matching earrings along with her striped, flowing chiffon Jenny Peckham gown. Felicity Jones chose a more discreet look with Bulgari diamonds studs and ring.
Viola Davis, Best Supporting Actress winner at the BAFTAs, accessorised her electric-blue Jenny Packham gown with a high jewellery Serpenti bracelet and earrings, both by Bulgari. Credit: Getty Images
BAFTA award winner Viola Davis wore iconic Bulgari Serpenti jewels - a high jewellery bracelet and earrings - on the red carpet in London.

Penelope Cruz, draped in a shimmering golden gown, added a pop of colour with a rubellite and diamond ring from Chopard‚Äôs Temptations collection.
Isabelle Huppert‚Äôs BAFTAs jewels included these shoulder-grazing Chopard high jewellery emerald earrings, which feature diamond stars raining down from both ears.
Star Wars heroine Daisy Ridley shone in chic Roland Mouret, paired with a bold yet simple Cartier Nouvelle Vague black lacquer and diamond cuff and two pairs of diamond earrings in her ears.
Presenter of the award for Best Supporting Actor at last night‚Äôs BAFTAs, Felicity Jones paired her vintage Dior dress with diamonds: a pair of studs and a high jewellery ring by Bulgari.
Red carpet favourite Nicole Kidman, nominee for Best Actress in a Supporting Role, pulled off more than 130 carats of Harry Winston diamonds, including an elaborate Caftan diamond tassel necklace. Credit: Getty Images
Emma Stone picked up her award for Leading Actress in a Chanel ensemble of dress and trousers with barely any jewellery visible apart from some discreet Tiffany diamond earrings and a pearl anklet.
Bucking the trend for opulent embroidery, Nicole Kidman,top, nominated for her role in Lion, turned up in a sleek, daringly deep-cut, slit-to-the-navel number by Giorgio Armani to show off 67 carats of diamonds in the Harry WinstonCaftan necklace.
Penelope Cruz, draped in a shimmering golden gown, added a pop of colour with a rubellite and diamond ring from Chopard‚Äôs Temptations collection.
Chopard, never far from a red carpet, bejewelled Penelope Cruz, above, and Isabelle Huppert, below. Cruz, draped in a golden gown of many swags, added a pop of colour with a candy-bright rubellite and diamond ring from the aptly named Chopard Temptations collection. French actress Isabelle Huppert also wore Chopard, with 68 carats of emeralds and 14 carats of diamonds in her lobes alone.

With each publication, JK Rowling grows ever more glamorous and looked a true celebrity on the red carpet in her deep-pink, floor-sweeping Roland Mouret gown. Showing a very personal take on jewellery styles, Rowling chose an edgy Yprem diamond hand bracelet ‚Äì something of a speciality for this Lebanese jewellery house ‚Äì with big diamond swirl earrings.
New-to-the-scene jeweller, Kat Florence, sponsored the after party, where Amy Adams posed with her for the obligatory sponsor‚Äôs shot wearing David Webb jewels and Millie Brady donned a pair of Kat Florence Tropicana diamond drop earrings.

the prestigious BAFTA Awards. The couple arrived in style, with the Duchess dazzling in a stunning emerald green gown that complemented her elegant demeanor. The event, which celebrates the best in film, saw a star-studded lineup, including Hollywood heavyweights and rising talents alike.

As anyone with 175 career games under his belt surely knows, nothing lasts forever. Cardinals quarterback Carson Palmer knows he isn‚Äôt getting any younger.
The veteran had most of his best years with the Bengals but, after a trade from Oakland to Arizona in 2013, he led the Cardinals to a 10-6 season ‚Äî their best record since 2009.
He posted a 63.3 completion percentage for 4,274 yards, his best passing efficiency since 2007 (64.9 percent) and a then-career high in single-season passing yards.
MORE: Bickley: Cardinals' Carson Palmer can't wait for his last shot
Palmer suffered a torn ACL that derailed his 2014 season but Palmer was better than ever in 2015.
The veteran set career highs in wins (13), passing yards (4,671), yards per attempt (8.7) and QBR (78.6). Pro Football Focus named him a first-team All Pro; Palmer had never been named to any all-pro team by any publication.
However, the 37-year-old quarterback experienced a clear decline in performance in 2016, posting career lows since his time in Oakland in categories across the board.
Cardinals coach Bruce Arians talks with Carson Palmer (3) during a game against Washington on Dec. 4. (Photo: Michael Chow/azcentral sports)
The drop-off has called into question Palmer‚Äôs chances for a bounce-back season.
‚ÄúI feel great. My body feels great like everybody in the league right now,‚Äù Palmer said in a conference call on Tuesday. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited about this year, this group and the opportunity in front of us.‚Äù
For Palmer, feeling is everything. For a player fifth among active quarterbacks in sack percentage (5 percent), it‚Äôs important to apply regular oversight to his health.
In fact, Palmer has been performing his yearly self-checkup since before his breakout 2015 campaign. The inflated numbers were nice to have, but it didn‚Äôt change how he viewed the rest of his career.
MORE: Cardinals' Carson Palmer says age is relative at QB position
‚ÄúI‚Äôve been telling my wife (for years) that this is the last one, but I take it one year at a time,‚Äù Palmer said. ‚ÄúI go through a process at end of the season to take stock.‚Äù
With lower expectations and an optimistic mindset, Palmer is looking to get back to doing what he loves ‚Äî just playing the game.
‚ÄúI love the game, working out, studying, every facet of it,‚Äù Palmer said. ‚ÄúAs long as I have the ability and the health to play, and continue to enjoy it, I don‚Äôt want to stop.‚Äù
The underdog
Palmer believes the Cardinals‚Äô 7-8-1 record in 2016 could be the best thing to happen to the team ‚Äî and to him.
It‚Äôs an interesting disposition, especially considering that just a season prior the Cardinals claimed their first NFC West title since 2009 and won 13 games for the first time in franchise history. They also earned a first-round bye in the playoffs, another first for Arizona.
The Palmer-led Cardinals made a statement with a 26-20 overtime win over the Green Bay Packers in the divisional round at University of Phoenix Stadium, but could not contain Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers in a 49-15 road drubbing in the NFC title game.
MORE: Cardinals had more fun this spring, Bruce Arians says
Still, expectations remained high for the Cardinals entering 2016.
This, Palmer maintains, spelled doom for him and his teammates. But this year, the 14-year veteran signal caller is looking forward to being in a familiar role.
‚ÄúI prefer the underdog role, and people are talking about other teams this year,‚Äù Palmer said. ‚ÄúIt allows you to go about your work, not having to answer some questions that come with a 13-3 season.‚Äù
Palmer can feel the difference.
‚ÄúI think there is definitely (less pressure),‚Äù Palmer said. ‚ÄúComing off a below .500 season, it gives you a little more time to focus on your craft, doing your job, and I think our team prefers the underdog style as well.‚Äù
MORE: Carson Palmer on NFL's highest paid player list

The second-quarter earnings season has been hailed by Wall Street‚Äôs equity bulls, who point to the better-than-expected results as proof that the stock market‚Äôs lofty levels were justified by the rise of activity in U.S. corporations.
S&P earnings grew 11% in the second quarter, the second straight quarter of double-digit growth, according to data from Goldman Sachs, the fastest two quarters of growth since 2011. More than half of S&P companies topped forecasts, the highest percentage since the second quarter of 2010, although the average upside surprise was 4%, slightly below the long-term average of 5%.
Despite the strength in the quarter, results in the first half of the year ‚Äúhave not been strong enough to warrant positive S&P 500 [earnings per share] revisions,‚Äù Goldman Sachs wrote in a note to clients. Of the S&P 500‚Äôs 11 primary sectors, it noted, forecasts for 2018‚Äôs profits have come down for six of them.
The average estimate of analysts polled by FactSet see S&P 500 SPX, +1.00% earnings of $141.81 a share in 2018. That‚Äôs down 0.2% from the $142.15 a share estimate that was forecast at the end of June.
Forecasts have come down even more for the remainder of the current year. For 2017, analysts see earnings of $130.46 a share for the S&P 500. That‚Äôs down 3.5% from the $135.25 that was forecast at the end of April. The S&P has risen 3.5% since that date.
It isn‚Äôt uncommon for estimates to be pared back as analysts and investors get more clarity about what economic conditions will look like, and the current tapering of expectations is less severe than is typical. The 0.2% decline for 2018 earnings is narrower than the 2% reduction that is typical when investors look out to the coming year, while the view for the second half of the year is also milder. Whereas forecasts have come down by 4% since March, per Goldman, the 30-year average reduction in estimates is 9%.
Opinion: The charts say S&P is heading into a ‚Äòtreacherous‚Äô pullback
Despite that, the investment bank‚Äîled by chief U.S. equity strategist David Kostin‚Äîexpects 2018 forecasts to drop 5% from current levels. In particular, it wrote that the market consensus was ‚Äúoverly optimistic primarily on energy earnings growth.‚Äù
Even though major U.S. stock-market indexes rose throughout the second-quarter earnings season, with both the Dow DJIA, +0.62% and the Nasdaq COMP, +1.34% hitting records, there were signs that investors were unimpressed even with better-than-expected results in the quarter.
According to data from BlackRock, U.S. companies that topped consensus forecasts on both earnings and sales barely rose in the day after their earnings, relative to their benchmark. In the first quarter, such companies outperformed by nearly 1%, in aggregate.
In comparison, stocks from Europe, Japan, or emerging markets that posted better-than-expected results saw much more pronounced rises in the second quarter. Meanwhile, U.S. companies that just missed on revenue sold off more than stocks from other regions that did, while the names that reported worse-than-expected results on both metrics were sharply punished following the results.
‚ÄúEquity markets have greeted positive earnings reports largely with indifference. Investor sentiment shows more signs of fatigue than euphoria, even as stock markets have repeatedly reached new highs this year,‚Äù said Richard Turnill, BlackRock‚Äôs global chief investment strategist.
Investors ‚Äúmay be on to something,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúIt will be more difficult for companies to achieve the same EPS growth in the second half, as the earnings recovery in the second half of 2016 is a higher hurdle.‚Äù
Despite that, he forecast ‚Äúsolid fundamentals and returns‚Äù going forward, ‚Äúwith the latter largely tracking earnings growth.‚Äù

...resilience of corporate earnings. Major companies across various sectors have reported stronger-than-anticipated profits, driven by robust consumer spending and effective cost management strategies. Analysts noted that sectors such as technology and consumer discretionary have particularly outperformed, with firms leveraging innovation and adapting to changing market conditions.

Investors are now looking ahead to the third quarter, where expectations remain cautiously optimistic. However, concerns about inflation and potential interest rate hikes linger, prompting some market participants to question the sustainability of this growth. Despite these headwinds, many analysts believe that the underlying fundamentals of the economy remain strong, providing a solid foundation for continued market performance.

As earnings reports continue to roll in, the focus will shift to guidance for the remainder of the year, with investors eager to gauge how companies plan to navigate the evolving economic landscape. The upcoming weeks will be crucial in determining whether the current bullish sentiment can be maintained.

LEXINGTON, Ky. ‚Äì The 2018-19 Kentucky roster has been left without a scholarship junior or senior again ‚Äî at least for now.
Sophomore forward Wenyen Gabriel announced Wednesday he will begin his professional career instead of returning to school for his junior season.
‚ÄúBBN, thank you for supporting me for the last two years and being patient with me through these last few weeks,‚Äù Gabriel said in a video posted to Twitter. ‚ÄúThis process hasn‚Äôt been easy for me and it‚Äôs choosing between a lifelong dream and playing in front of a fan base that I‚Äôve grown to love so much. Opportunities like these don‚Äôt come without the support and encouragement from my family, Coach Cal, the coaching staff, my teammates, and of course, the fans.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve enjoyed every moment of this journey at the University of Kentucky and I just want to thank everyone for who has supported me through both my ups and my downs. Lord knows this hasn‚Äôt been easy, but my time here has only better prepared me for what the future has for me.
‚ÄúAfter receiving positive feedback, my dreams of becoming a professional basketball player are that much closer to reality. I believe that I‚Äôm ready to take that jump and will be keeping my name in the 2018 draft.‚Äù
To the best fans in the world, I couldn‚Äôt be more honored to have worn that Kentucky name across my chest for the p‚Ä¶ twitter.com/i/web/status/1‚Ä¶ ‚Äî
UPMŒõN‚Ñ¢ (@WenyenGabriel) May 30, 2018
Gabriel declared for the draft without hiring an agent on April 18 despite not being including among ESPN's top 100 prospects for the 2018 draft, saying he was confident he could "play at the next level" but wanted to be "absolutely certain" starting his professional career was the right decision at this time by eliciting feedback from NBA teams.
Of the six UK players who declared for the draft after the season, Gabriel was the only one not to receive an invitation to the NBA's scouting combine.
As a sophomore, Gabriel, a former South Sudanese refugee who grew up in New Hampshire after moving to the United States as a toddler, averaged 6.8 points and 5.4 rebounds per game while starting seven of Kentucky's 37 games. He shot 39.6 percent (42-for-106) from 3-point range and led the Wildcats with 40 blocked shots.
It's NBA draft decision day: Will these UK players return next season?
You may like: John Calipari talking to NBA teams about UK players testing out draft
Also: PJ Washington withdraws from NBA draft and will return to Kentucky
The highlight of Gabriel's season came in the SEC Tournament semifinals when he hit all 7 of his 3-point attempts en route to a team-high 23 points in a win over Alabama.
"Wenyen‚Äôs game is where the league continues to trend towards,‚Äù UK head coach John Calipari said in a news release confirming the decision. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a position-less big man who can shoot, guard multiple positions and is willing to do what it takes to win. Wenyen grew so much from his freshman season to his sophomore year. If he continues to make those same strides, he‚Äôs going to carve himself a role with a team. He and I have talked and he knows he‚Äôs going to have to work hard to get there, but I‚Äôm confident he can.‚Äù
Since the end of the season, UK has lost Kevin Knox, Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Hamidou Diallo to the draft and Sacha Killeya-Jones and Tai Wynyard to transfers.
Freshman forward PJ Washington announced he was returning to UK earlier Wednesday, and multiple national reports suggested the Wildcats could add Stanford graduate transfer Reid Travis to next season's roster.
Both Washington and Travis play Gabriel's position. UK also will feature 2017-18 starter Nick Richards and five-star recruit EJ Montgomery in the post positions, clogging the path to the number of minutes Gabriel might have needed to improve his stock.
At the combine earlier this month, Calipari said he had talked with multiple teams that had worked out Gabriel.
"One team told me yes, the other team told me no," Calipari said. "But the good news about this league: You only have to have one team that likes you. The other 29 can say you stink, but if that one likes you, they take you."
Gabriel seems likely to start his professional career overseas or in the NBA's developmental league.
Travis will be a fifth-year senior next season. His addition would ensure Kentucky does not play a second consecutive season without a scholarship junior or senior, but for now Washington, Richards and point guard Quade Green, each entering their second season at Kentucky, are the most experienced scholarship players on the roster.

...forgo his remaining eligibility and declare for the NBA Draft. Gabriel, who averaged 5.1 points and 4.0 rebounds per game last season, expressed his gratitude to the coaching staff and fans in a heartfelt statement. "I want to thank Coach Calipari and my teammates for believing in me and pushing me to be my best," Gabriel said. "This program has been a huge part of my life, and I‚Äôm excited to take the next step in my career."

His decision comes as a surprise to many, as he had shown flashes of potential throughout the season, particularly in key games. With Gabriel's departure, Kentucky will continue to focus on recruiting top talent to fill the void. Coach John Calipari is expected to bring in a strong class of freshmen, aiming to maintain the program's competitive edge in the SEC and nationally. The Wildcats will look to rebound from a disappointing tournament exit and build for the future.
