Freeman's apology has been met with mixed reactions, as some commend his acknowledgment of the allegations while others feel it falls short of taking full responsibility for his actions.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. (AP) ‚Äî Emboldened and proclaiming victory after a bloody weekend in Virginia, white nationalists are planning more demonstrations to promote their agenda following the violence that left a woman dead and dozens injured.
The University of Florida said white provocateur Richard Spencer, whose appearances sometimes stoke unrest, is seeking permission to speak there next month. And white nationalist Preston Wiginton said he is planning a ‚ÄúWhite Lives Matter‚Äù rally at Texas A&M University in September.
Also, a neo-Confederate group has asked the state of Virginia for permission to rally at a monument to Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee in Richmond on Sept. 16, and other events are likely.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to be more active than ever before,‚Äù Matthew Heimbach, a white nationalist leader, said Monday.
James Alex Fields Jr., a young man who was said to idolize Adolf Hitler and Nazi Germany in high school, was charged with killing a woman by slamming a car into a group of counter-protesters at a white nationalist rally Sunday in Charlottesville, Virginia.
Fields, 20, who recently moved to Ohio from his home state of Kentucky, was held without bail on murder charges. He was photographed at the rally behind a shield bearing the emblem of the white nationalist Vanguard America, though the group denied he was a member.
Two state troopers also died Sunday when their helicopter crashed during an effort to contain the violence.
The U.S. Justice Department said it will review the violence, and Attorney General Jeff Sessions told ABC that the death of counter-protester Heather Heyer, 32, met the definition of domestic terrorism.
White nationalists said they were undaunted.
Heimbach, who said he was pepper-sprayed during the melee in Charlottesville, called the event Saturday ‚Äúan absolute stunning victory‚Äù for the far right because of the large number of supporters who descended on the city to decry plans to remove a statue of Lee.
Hundreds of white nationalists, white supremacists, neo-Nazis, Ku Klux Klan members and others were involved, by some estimates, in what Heimbach, leader of the Traditionalist Workers Party, called the nation‚Äôs biggest such event in a decade or more. Even more opponents turned out, and the two sides clashed violently.
A neo-Nazi website that helped promote the gathering said there will be more events soon.
‚ÄúWe are going to start doing this nonstop. Across the country,‚Äù said the site, which internet domain host GoDaddy said it was shutting down after it mocked the woman killed in Charlottesville.
The head of the National Socialist Movement, Jeff Schoep, said Charlottesville was a ‚Äúreally good‚Äù white nationalist event that was being overshadowed by the deaths. ‚ÄúAny time someone loses their life it‚Äôs unfortunate,‚Äù he said.
He blamed the violence on inadequate police protection and counter-demonstrators and said he doubts white nationalists will be deterred from attending more such demonstrations.
Preserving memorials to the Old South has become an animating force for the white nationalist movement, not because all members are Southern, Schoep said, but because adherents see the drive to remove such monuments as part of a larger, anti-white crusade.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an assault on American freedoms. Today it‚Äôs Confederate monuments. Tomorrow it may be the Constitution or the American flag,‚Äù Schoep said.
At the University of Florida, where Spencer has asked to speak, President W. Kent Fuchs called the events in Virginia ‚Äúdeplorable‚Äù but indicated school officials might be unable to block his appearance.
‚ÄúWhile this speaker‚Äôs views do not align with our values as an institution, we must follow the law, upholding the First Amendment not to discriminate based on content and provide access to a public space,‚Äù Fuchs said in a message on the university‚Äôs Facebook page.
Auburn University spent almost $30,000 in legal fees in an unsuccessful attempt to prevent Spencer from speaking on its campus in Alabama in April.

...one dead and dozens injured. The clashes in Charlottesville, which erupted during a rally against the removal of a Confederate statue, have sparked outrage and condemnation across the nation. Leaders of various white nationalist groups have announced their intention to hold additional rallies in other cities, claiming their right to free speech and expressing defiance against what they describe as "political correctness."

Local authorities are bracing for potential unrest, with many cities considering increased security measures to prevent violence. Activist groups are also mobilizing, planning counter-protests to challenge the ideologies of the white nationalists. The events have reignited a national conversation about race, hate speech, and the legacy of Confederate symbols in America. As tensions rise, community leaders are urging dialogue and understanding, while others call for stricter regulations on hate groups. The aftermath of the weekend's violence continues to resonate, leaving many questioning the future of civil discourse in the country.

NEW YORK (Reuters) - A lawyer for U.S. President Donald Trump‚Äôs longtime personal attorney, Michael Cohen, on Wednesday accused adult film actress Stormy Daniels‚Äô lawyer of leaking Cohen‚Äôs bank records to the press, calling it a ‚Äúdrive-by shooting of my client‚Äôs rights.‚Äù
U.S. President Donald Trump's personal lawyer Michael Cohen leaves federal court in Manhattan, New York, U.S., May 30, 2018. REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton
The comments by Cohen lawyer Stephen Ryan regarding Daniels‚Äô lawyer, Michael Avenatti, came during an often-heated hearing before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood in Manhattan related to a criminal investigation by federal prosecutors into Cohen‚Äôs business dealings.
Avenatti told Wood he did not release anything improper about Cohen, who has not been charged with a crime.
But the judge told Avenatti he would not have free rein in her courtroom ‚Äúto denigrate Mr. Cohen and, I believe, potentially, deprive him of a fair trial by tainting a jury pool‚Äù should criminal charges be brought against Cohen.
Leaks could make it harder for Cohen to get a fair trial if he were charged. Legal experts have said he might choose to cooperate with prosecutors as pressure mounts.
The investigation stems in part from a referral by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is probing whether Trump‚Äôs 2016 presidential campaign colluded with Russia.
U.S. President Donald Trump's personal lawyer Michael Cohen arrives at federal court in Manhattan, New York, U.S., May 30, 2018. REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton
Trump has repeatedly denied any collusion, and Russia has denied meddling in the U.S. election.
At Wednesday‚Äôs hearing, Wood set a June 15 deadline for Cohen‚Äôs and Trump‚Äôs lawyers to identify materials seized in April raids on his home, office and hotel room, which they say prosecutors cannot use by prosecutors because the materials are subject to attorney-client privilege.
Wood said a ‚Äútaint team‚Äù of prosecutors not involved in the Cohen probe would make the determinations after that date.
Ryan, one of Cohen‚Äôs lawyers, said in court that Avenatti acted maliciously by releasing his client‚Äôs bank records and attacking Cohen in dozens of media appearances, to ‚Äúpaint a false narrative‚Äù about Cohen and ‚Äúcall attention to himself.‚Äù
Slideshow (8 Images)
Avenatti has released details of payments to Cohen from a company linked to Russian oligarch Viktor Vekselberg, who the United States sanctioned over suspected meddling in the election.
Avenatti‚Äôs involvement has complicated the Cohen probe.
Daniels, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, has said she had a sexual encounter with Trump, and sued Cohen in March to end an agreement under which Cohen paid her $130,000 not to discuss it. Trump has denied having sex with Daniels.
Speaking to reporters after the hearing, Avenatti signaled that more disclosures are forthcoming.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got a whole host of information that we are going to be releasing relating to Mr. Cohen and relating to Mr. Trump, so they better buckle up,‚Äù he said.
The June 15 deadline to review documents seized from Cohen was a month sooner than Cohen‚Äôs lawyers had wanted.
Todd Harrison, a lawyer for Cohen, said his firm was ‚Äúmoving heaven and Earth‚Äù to review documents. He said they have reviewed about 1.3 million of the 3.7 million files turned over.
But the judge said taking too long was not an option.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important for the court to balance the slow, deliberate needs of those asserting attorney-client privilege with the need for an investigation to go forward,‚Äù Wood said.

...to the media in an attempt to undermine Cohen's credibility. The lawyer, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, claimed that the release of the financial documents was a deliberate act to sway public opinion against Cohen as he cooperates with federal investigations.

Daniels' attorney, Michael Avenatti, denied the allegations, asserting that the information was obtained through legal means and was in the public interest. "We will not be intimidated by Cohen or his legal team," Avenatti stated during a press conference. 

The controversy centers around a $130,000 payment made to Daniels shortly before the 2016 presidential election, which Cohen has admitted to facilitating. This payment has raised questions about campaign finance violations and the extent of Trump's knowledge and involvement. As investigations continue, both sides are preparing for a legal battle that could have significant implications for the Trump administration.

Cubs' Kris Bryant reacts after reaching second base on an RBI double in the sixth inning on Friday. (Photo: Pablo Martinez Monsivais, Associated Press)
Washington ‚Äî Kyle Hendricks goes about things completely differently than Stephen Strasburg does on the mound.
The kid from Dartmouth relies on a fastball that on a good day reaches 88 mph ‚Äî about 10 mph slower than Strasburg‚Äôs ‚Äî and a deceptive changeup. Instead of power, he gets by on precision, guile and smarts.
Hendricks outpitched Strasburg in Game 1 of the NL Division Series, giving up only two hits in seven innings to help the Chicago Cubs open defense of their first World Series title in 108 years by beating the Washington Nationals, 3-0, on Friday night.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why we call him Professor,‚Äù Chicago second baseman Javier Baez said about Hendricks. ‚ÄúHe knows what he‚Äôs doing.‚Äù
Kris Bryant and Anthony Rizzo produced RBI singles with two outs in the sixth inning for the first two hits off an otherwise-dominant Strasburg. Rizzo added a run-scoring double in the eighth off Ryan Madson.
Carl Edwards Jr. threw a perfect inning and Wade Davis finished the two-hitter for a save.
Unlike No. 1 overall draft pick Strasburg, Hendricks went in the eighth round. Unlike Strasburg, Hendricks has never been an All-Star. Unlike Strasburg, who already has signed a $175 million, seven-year deal that begins next season, Hendricks earned less than $800,000 in 2017.
But this was Hendricks‚Äô time to shine.
‚ÄúHe was tricking us tonight,‚Äù Nationals manager Dusty Baker said, ‚Äúand seems like those kind of guys give us more trouble than guys who throw hard.‚Äù
The slender righty, who led the NL in ERA last season, gave up a single in the first and another in the second ‚Äî and that was it for the Nationals.
He walked three batters and struck out six.
‚ÄúHe knows the scouting report,‚Äù said Jon Lester, who starts Game 2 on Saturday for Chicago against fellow lefty Gio Gonzalez. ‚ÄúHe knows where guys‚Äô weaknesses are.‚Äù
Harper ‚Äî wearing shoes with ‚ÄúPray for Las Vegas‚Äù written on the side following the recent mass shooting in his hometown ‚Äî was 1 for 4 as he tries to regain his timing after returning last week from a 42-game injury absence. Otherwise, Washington‚Äôs elite hitters ‚Äî Anthony Rendon, Ryan Zimmerman, Daniel Murphy, Trea Turner and Jayson Werth ‚Äî were a combined 0 for 17 with three walks.
‚ÄúDefinitely, your confidence builds,‚Äù Hendricks said, ‚Äúwhen you start seeing those swings.‚Äù
The fact that Hendricks approached 90 mph as often as he did was an aberration he and teammates attributed to adrenaline, but one that helped, of course.
He also knew he needed to be really good, because of what Strasburg was doing.
Strasburg didn‚Äôt allow a hit until there were two outs in the sixth. Baez reached on Rendon‚Äôs error at third base to start the inning and was sacrificed to second by Hendricks. One out later, Bryant drove in the first run with a single to right-center and went to second when Harper‚Äôs throw missed the cutoff man.
Bryant, Rizzo said, managed to ‚Äúget the monkey off the back in the dugout for all of us.‚Äù
Rizzo followed by singling to right in front of a diving Harper to make it 2-0.
With a heavy beard and a lot of sweat on a muggy, 77-degree night, Strasburg dialed up his fastball to 98 mph and mixed in an unhittable changeup. To cheers of ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go, Strasburg!‚Äù from many in a sellout crowd of 43,898, he struck out 10 to set a playoff record for the Expos-Nationals franchise.
Strasburg wound up allowing just those two unearned runs in seven innings, with three hits and one walk.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre aware of it,‚Äù Hendricks said about Strasburg. ‚ÄúYou know how well he‚Äôs throwing on the other side.‚Äù
Hendricks threw well, too.
‚ÄúIt was,‚Äù Cubs catcher Willson Contreras said, ‚Äúa masterpiece.‚Äù

...his business quietly, but his impact on the mound speaks volumes. The Chicago Cubs' right-hander delivered a masterful performance against the Washington Nationals, showcasing his trademark precision and poise. Hendricks allowed just two runs over seven innings, striking out six and walking none, as he kept the Nationals' lineup off balance with his mix of pitches.

The Cubs' offense supported him well, with Kris Bryant's RBI double in the sixth inning providing a crucial insurance run. Bryant's hit came at a pivotal moment, extending the Cubs' lead and energizing the dugout. "We needed that hit to keep the momentum going," Hendricks said after the game. 

The Cubs' bullpen held strong in the final frames, sealing the victory and giving the team a much-needed boost in the playoff race. With this win, the Cubs continue to chase a postseason berth, and Hendricks' steady hand will be vital in the coming weeks.

The official countdown to the Norwood Fair has begun, with the 46th Annual Ambassador of the Fair Competition held on August 13 at the Norwood Community Centre. Congratulations to the newly crowned 2017-2018 Ambassador Alexa Vanderhorst. Alexa received her crown, official sash and bouquet of roses from out-going Ambassador Tori English.
With great poise and confidence three gifted and enthusiastic young ladies competed in front of a room full of friends and family this past Sunday, vying for the title of 2017-2018 Norwood Fair Ambassador. The contestants were each required to complete an interview with the judges, deliver a short speech demonstrating their knowledge of the fair and what it means to them, plus answer an impromptu question.
New fair ambassador Alexa was sponsored by Oakland Greens Golf and Country Club and will be starting her grade 12 year at Norwood District High School in the fall. Alexa is the daughter of Norwood's Will and Bernadette Vanderhorst. Alexa follows the fine example set by her family and is heavily involved in community activities. She is a volunteer for the local chapter of the IODE, a participant and volunteer with the Peterborough County Dairy Farmers, she is an accomplished skater and volunteer with the Norwood and District Figure Skating Club and as a sports enthusiast, she participates and volunteers her time with Norwood Minor Sports, the Havelock Soccer Club, as well as the Pagans Rugby Club. Family is an important part of Alexa's life, naming her father Will as one of the most inspiring people in her life by consistently demonstrating to her the importance of family and hard work and the importance of agriculture. Her future plans include pursuing a career in criminal justice and law enforcement. Her favourite part of the fair is entering her vegetables and baking in the homecraft and school divisions.
This year's first runner up is Emily Beriault, sponsored by J.J. Stewart Motors. Emily is the daughter of Tim and Carrie Beriault of Westwood and will be starting her Grade 12 year at Norwood District High School in the fall. Emily participates in a variety of local sporting activities including soccer and hockey; she is a talented artist with a keen interest in art, drawing, photography and singing.
This year's second runner up is Emma Beavis, sponsored by the Norwood Lions Club. Emma is the daughter of Jeff and Cheryl Beavis from Hastings and will be starting her Grade 12 year at Norwood District High School in the fall. Emma is also a sports enthusiast, playing on several school teams and volunteering as a referee for several community teams.
The three judges included a former Douro resident, Dan Moloney who is a Peterborough based Financial Adviser and volunteer board member for several committee's and societies. Eileen Kimmett of Peterborough is a keen volunteer for her children's school as well as for many community boards, societies and events. Patty Thompson is a past fair ambassador for the Millbrook Agricultural Society. She is an elementary teacher and a board member with the Down Syndrome Association of Peterborough.
Thanks go the participants and their families, the businesses who sponsor the contestants and to the volunteers who organize the competition each year. And I would be remiss to not thank Megan Wilson of Megan Wilson Photography for suppling her impressive picture taking talents to record the day's memories.
The well attended celebration concluded with refreshments, cake and of course congratulations.
norwoodnews@nexicom.net

...winners of this year‚Äôs competition, who will represent the fair throughout the upcoming festivities. This year‚Äôs ambassadors, Emily Johnson and Liam Carter, impressed the judges with their poise, community involvement, and knowledge of the fair‚Äôs history. 

The Norwood Fair, scheduled for September 7-10, promises to be a vibrant celebration of local culture, featuring a variety of events including agricultural showcases, live entertainment, and delicious food vendors. Families can look forward to carnival rides, games, and the popular petting zoo, which has become a staple attraction for children and adults alike.

In addition to the traditional events, this year‚Äôs fair will introduce new activities such as a craft beer garden and a local artisans market, highlighting the talents of Norwood‚Äôs creative community. Organizers encourage everyone to mark their calendars and join in the fun, as the fair continues to be a cherished tradition that brings the community together.

It is clear now that Delhi Chief Minister has given up his brand of combative (AAP) supremo Kejriwal launched into an apology spree and apologised to Congress leader Kapil Sibal's son Amit Sibal and Union minister and Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) leader for making unverified allegations of corruption against them. The development came days after Kejriwal apologised to former Punjab minister Bikram Singh Majithia. After he tendered his apology, Kejriwal was acquitted in two separate defamation cases lodged against him by Amit Sibal, a senior advocate and son of former Union minister Kapil Sibal, and Gadkari. Deputy Chief Minister Manish Sisodia, a co-accused with Kejriwal in the lodged by Sibal, was also acquitted after he, too, tendered an apology to the lawyer. Kejriwal intends to bring an end to the 33 defamation cases against him by means of similar out-of-court settlements and individual "understandings", say sources. According to AAP leaders, the various cases have drained the party's resources and money. The Congress and the BJP, however, hauled Kejriwal over the coals. The Opposition party advised that the Delhi chief minister should change his name to Arvind 'Sorry' Kejriwal, while the ruling party at the Centre lashed out at the AAP chief's brand of The AAP chief has been dragged to courts in multiple defamation cases lodged by various political leaders, including Union Finance Minister Arun Jaitley and former Delhi chief minister Kejriwal still has to contend with Jaitley's case, and sources in the AAP had told news agencies last week that the senior BJP leader could also soon receive an apology from the Delhi chief minister. Last week, Kejriwal wrote to Akali Dal leader Bikram Majithia, apologising for accusing him of being involved in drug trade without any proof to back the allegations. The apology, however, did not go down to well with everyone and triggered what amounted to a virtual rebellion in the AAP Punjab unit. Subsequently, Bhagwant Mann resigned as AAP's Punjab unit chief. However, things seem to have improved since Kejriwal's meeting with AAP members of the Punjab legislative Assembly, with most saying they understand the decision of the party's convenor. Amit Sibal had filed a defamation suit against Kejriwal and Sisodia for alleging that Kapil Sibal had a conflict in seeking to revise a tax demand on telecom major Vodafone. In 2014, Gadkari had filed a defamation suit against Kejriwal after the AAP chief named him in a list of "corrupt politicians". In the filed by Gadkari, it was alleged that Kejriwal had called him "India's most corrupt". Here are the top 10 developments in Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal's apology spree that has so far covered Majithia, Sibal and Gadkari: 1) BJP says 'anarchic character' of Kejriwal's exposed: BJP's Delhi unit chief Manoj Tiwari took a dig at Kejriwal and his apologies, stating that the "anarchic character" of the "NGO politics" practised by the Delhi chief minister now stood exposed before the people of the country. Tiwari also alleged that Kejriwal was a regular violator of the law and that he had, in connivance with a section of the media preferring to run anti-establishment news, "misused" the Right to Information Act against his political opponents. 2) Shivraj Singh Chouhan has a piece of advice for the AAP chief: Kejriwal, who has received much ridicule over his apologies, given his past brand of politics, also received some advice on how to go about his apology spree. The Delhi chief minister's Madhya Pradesh counterpart, Shivraj Singh Chouhan, tweeted a piece of advice: "Arvind-ji, if you heed my suggestion then make a list of people that you need to apologise to and prepare an apology letter headed 'To whomsoever it may concern'. "This would save you the hassle of apologising repeatedly," Chouhan's tweet said. ALSO READ: Kejriwal's 'sorry' syndrome: Shivraj Singh Chouhan's advice to Delhi CM 3) Congress says AAP chief should change his name: The Congress on Monday advised the Delhi Chief Minister to change his name to Arvind 'Sorry' Kejriwal, adding that this is what happened when "one does for sensationalism". Congress spokesperson Randeep Singh Surjwala said, "There is a sorry Chief Minister in the country. He should change his name to Arvind Sorry Kejriwal. This is just the beginning of his trail of saying sorry, and not the end." "He also has to apologise to the people of Delhi and the country, whom he has deceived," added Surjwala. "He also has to apologise for poor governance. When you do only for sensationalism, and not for balance, then this going to be the consequence," said the Congress leaders, adding, "The propaganda which was spread by him and his associates in collusion with BJP-RSS at Ram Leela Maidan during UPA rule, the truth of it has come out." "Delhi is sorry to have Kejriwal and his government," he added. 4) Sisodia says don't want to waste time on defamation cases: Defending his party chief's apologies to Majithia, Gadkari, and Sibal, Delhi Deputy Chief Minister said on Monday that he would use his time in service of the people instead of doing rounds of the courts for defamation cases filed against him and Kejriwal. "We will apologise to the people we have hurt. We're here to serve the people; we do not have the time to go to courts for such issues," said Sisodia, adding, "We're here to build schools and hospitals for the welfare of people."
ALSO READ: Kejriwal says sorry to Gadkari, Sibal, Majithia; Arun Jaitley next? updates Sources have told news agencies that Kejriwal intends to bring an end to all the defamation cases against him, which reportedly number 33, by means of similar out of court settlements and individual "understandings". According to AAP leaders, the various cases have drained the party's resources and money.
5) says Kejriwal backing off 'meekly': Displeased by his string of apologies, Displeased by his string of apologies, former AAP leader attacked Arvind Kejriwal , asking the AAP chief why he had published a list of 20 "corrupt politicians" if he wanted to "back off meekly". Further, Damania rejected Kejriwal's contention that he wanted to focus his strength in Delhi.
"Ideally, with a strong MLA force of 67 out of 70 MLAs, he should have entrusted the functioning of the Delhi government to his trusted MLAs and fought each one of the cases and ensured victory in every single matter and punish(ed) these corrupt politicians," she said. "It is extremely upsetting to see Arvind seeking apology from Gadkari despite concrete evidences given by me. Why on the earth had the AAP issued a list of 20 most corrupt politicians if they were to back off meekly?" added Damania.
Damania was once a key associate of Kejriwal. She had accused Gadkari of irregularities in his Purti Group of companies. Kejriwal, for his part, had gone on to name Gadkari as one of the most corrupt politicians in India. Taking objection to this, Gadkari had moved the court against Kejriwal for allegedly defaming him.
Besides spear-heading the campaign against Gadkari, Damania had also contested against him from Nagpur in the Lok Sabha polls 2014.
ALSO READ: Kejriwal apologises to Majithia; AAP, SAD-BJP leaders upset; 10 highlights Damania added that she still has 24 defamation cases against her and that she would fight them out until the end. Damania had quit AAP in 2015 at a time when the party was witnessing an ugly spat between and Yogendra Yadav on one side and Kejriwal on the other.
6) acquitted in Gadkari and Sibal defamation cases: Despite the criticism, Despite the criticism, AAP's apology strategy does seem to be paying off , at least as far as dealing with the defamation cases is concerned, concerns over how it will impact the party's political image notwithstanding. Kejriwal was on Monday acquitted in the two separate defamation cases lodged against him by Gadkari and Amit Sibal after he issued an apology to both of them.
After also tendered an apology to Amit Sibal through a letter, Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate Samar Vishal acquitted the deputy Delhi chief minister, who was a co-accused along with Kejriwal in the lodged by Sibal.
The relief came from the court after the apologies were accepted by the complainants in both the cases.
ALSO READ: Punjab AAP unit to support Kejriwal, other politicians miffed: 10 updates However, the proceedings against lawyer and BJP leader Shazia Ilmi will continue in the lodged by Amit Sibal.
7) Kejriwal opposes second Rs 100-million defamation suit by Jaitley in HC: In the Delhi High Court, In the Delhi High Court, Kejriwal on Monday opposed the second Rs 100 million (Rs 10 crore) defamation suit against him by Arun Jaitley over the use of an objectionable word by the chief minister's former lawyer The AAP chief claimed that he had never instructed his then counsel, Jethmalani, to use any scandalous words against Jaitley during recording of his evidence.
Jaitley had filed the second defamation suit after Jethmalani allegedly "abused" him in the open court during the proceedings of the original defamation suit he had filed against the AAP chief and five other party functionaries.
However, the chief minister maintained that apart from the ground of "absolute privilege, the present suit is also barred by Section 126 of the Indian Evidence Act".
"The statement, upon which the suit is based on alleged defamatory imputations made by the senior advocate (without any oath), allegedly on the instructions of the defendant (Kejriwal), which he could not have disclosed," Kejriwal said in his written statement filed through advocate Anupam Srivastava.
Section 126 of the Evidence Act bars disclosure of any professional communication between an advocate and his client, including instructions given by the client in relation to his case.
During the cross-examination of the minister on May 17 last year before Joint Registrar in the Delhi High Court, Jethmalani had used a term Jaitley found objectionable.
ALSO READ: Kejriwal's string of apologies continues, latest to Gadkari, Amit Sibal The second suit filed through advocate Manik Dogra has said that the minister enjoyed a reputation of honesty and probity and had sacrificed large professional earnings in order to undertake public service.
8) Kejriwal apologises to Gadkari, Sibal: Days after Kejriwal regretted having accused Akali Dal leader Bikram Majithia of being involved in the drug trade, Days after Kejriwal regretted having accused Akali Dal leader Bikram Majithia of being involved in the drug trade, Kejriwal apologised to BJP leader and Union Minister and Congress leader Kapil Sibal for making unverified allegations of corruption against them. Both leaders withdrew their defamation cases against the AAP chief on Monday.
In a March 16 letter to Gadkari, Kejriwal said he was feeling sorry for making "certain statements, without regard to its verifiability, which seem to have hurt you...".
"I have nothing personal against you. I regret the same. Let us put the incident behind us and bring the court proceedings to a closure," said the letter.
Addressing the Union Shipping and Transport Minister, Kejriwal also suggested that "we should put our energy to serve the people of this country in the spirit of mutual respect".

9) Kejriwal tries to pacify dissenting Punjab AAP MLAs: On the backfoot after tendering an apology to Bikram Singh Majithia, the AAP on Sunday sought to On the backfoot after tendering an apology to Bikram Singh Majithia, the AAP on Sunday sought to pacify its party MLAs from Punjab in a bid to avert a split in the state unit. Kejriwal's apology letter to Majithia for accusing him of being involved in the drug trade took everyone by surprise, especially the AAP's Punjab unit.
The party's Punjab president Bhagwant Mann and its co-president Aman Arora resigned from their posts in protest against Kejriwal's apology.

Kejriwal's shift in tone comes amid growing pressure from various political factions and a need to mend fences ahead of the upcoming elections. His recent statements reflect a strategic pivot towards a more conciliatory approach, aiming to foster alliances rather than confrontations.

In a press conference, Kejriwal expressed regret for any hurt caused, emphasizing the importance of unity in the face of pressing issues facing the capital. "We may have our differences, but we must work together for the betterment of Delhi," he stated, signaling a willingness to collaborate with opposition parties.

Political analysts suggest that this change in strategy could be a calculated move to broaden AAP's appeal and secure crucial support from other parties. As the political landscape shifts, observers will be watching closely to see if this new approach will resonate with voters or if it will be seen as a sign of weakness.

As technology stocks sank on Monday, CNBC's Jim Cramer wanted to examine a name outside the line of fire: the stock of e-commerce platform Etsy.
Cramer was skeptical when Etsy first came public in 2015. But he changed his tune since the IPO, blessing the stock for speculation in May 2016 and recommending it again in August 2017.
Since last August, shares of Etsy have climbed 78 percent, and Cramer argued that the move was totally due to the company's fundamentals ‚Äî a good sign for prospective investors.
"A lot of people at one point were worried that Etsy would be steamrolled by Amazon after the retail 'Death Star' launched their own marketplace for handcrafted goods. Turns out Etsy is incredibly resilient," the "Mad Money" host said.
"We know that because Etsy's most recent quarter was a gigantic blowout," he continued. "So any chance to buy this thing into weakness is an opportunity."
Amazon's influence has proven to be a legitimate threat for online and brick-and-mortar retailers alike. But its push into the handmade market has not been enough to crush Etsy, which helps a network of nearly two million sellers compete in the digital retail space, Cramer said.
Most companies that compete with Amazon fear the online giant's scale, but in this case, scale is on Etsy's side, the "Mad Money" host continued.
Etsy has tens of millions of handmade goods for sale on its website; Amazon Handmade has less than one million, he noted.
Etsy has also been improving the buyer experience with better search and recommendation functions, which translated into better holiday sales and growth across all of its core markets.
Better yet, the company's 2017 management shakeup ‚Äî in which it brought in a new chief financial officer, a new chief technology officer and a new CEO ‚Äî went off without a hitch, Cramer said.
"And boy, oh boy, can this new team deliver," he said. "When Etsy reported its latest quarter last month, they knocked it out of the park."
Beating earnings and revenue estimates, Etsy's fourth quarter showed better-than-expected gross merchandise sellers, growth in its mobile business and a higher conversion rate, or the percentage of consumers who end up buying something after visiting Etsy's website.
Management also gave strong full-year guidance for 2018, kick-starting a more than 30 percent run in Etsy's stock before Monday's weakness hit.
"That is an epic run, which is why I'm so glad Etsy's finally pulling back with the rest of tech, down 1.66 percent today," Cramer said. "Ideally, it goes even lower and you get even better prices. I say 'ideally' because this sell-off has nothing to do with Etsy and I believe it will bounce back with alacrity once investors calm down."
Cramer acknowledged that shares of Etsy look expensive, currently valued at 53 times next year's earnings estimates. But based on the company's 2021 estimates, its valuation is only 29 times earnings, a better deal for a growth stock, he said.
"The bottom line? This was a really ugly day for the stock market, not denying it, but you need to stay calm. Approach sell-offs like this one as buying opportunities, at least when it comes to high-quality stocks of companies with great fundamentals," the "Mad Money" host said.
"Etsy's stock got hit today, but its business is in amazing shape. You have my blessing to pick some up here right now, tomorrow, even more if the pain continues, which may very well be the case given the ferocity of the Nasdaq portion of the sell-off."

...reported its latest earnings, noting that while the company had shown resilience during the pandemic, the post-COVID landscape posed new challenges. Cramer pointed out that Etsy's growth was heavily reliant on consumer spending, which could be affected by rising inflation and interest rates. He highlighted that the platform's unique selling proposition‚Äîhandmade and vintage items‚Äîmight not be enough to shield it from broader economic pressures.

Despite his concerns, Cramer acknowledged that Etsy had a loyal customer base and a strong brand identity. He suggested that investors should keep an eye on the company's ability to innovate and adapt to changing market conditions. Cramer also mentioned the importance of Etsy's efforts to enhance its seller tools and improve the overall shopping experience, which could help maintain its competitive edge. Ultimately, he advised caution, urging investors to weigh the potential risks against the company's long-term growth prospects before making any decisions.

Baysox squeak by Squirrels in series opener

Ten hits and a solid outing from lefty Matt Gage were not enough for Richmond on Monday as the Squirrels (4-7) dropped game one to the Bowie Baysox (7-4), 3-2 at Prince George‚Äôs Stadium. Bowie‚Äôs Austin Wynns smacked a three-run homer in the sixth inning to produce the lead. MLB right-hander Chris Tillman pitched 2 2/3 innings in a rehab assignment and allowed a solo home run to Carlos Garcia in the first.
It didn‚Äôt take long for Richmond to attack the MLB rehabber Chris Tillman. With one out in the first inning, Carlos Garcia drilled a solo home run over the right field wall to take a 1-0 lead. Tillman bookended the homer with a pair of strikeouts and retired the next six batters he faced.
Matt Gage pitched with traffic early on, but was able to navigate trouble. The lefty allowed a walk and a hit in the first inning and two more hits in the second. He picked up a double play with two on and one out in the third to keep Richmond in front 1-0. Gage threw 54 pitches through the first three innings of work.
Tillman ran into trouble in the third inning and had his rehab appearance cut short with two outs. Rando Moreno worked a walk to begin the third and Slade Heathcott roped a single to right. Tillman then induced a fly ball to right field before reaching his pitch limit. Lucas Long replaced Tillman and stranded both inherited runners. Tillman finished with one walk and three strikeouts. He allowed the one run on two hits in the no-decision.
After walking the tightrope through the first three innings, Gage settled in and picked up the pace. The lefty retired the side in the fourth inning and cruised until he hit the batter Drew Dosch to start the sixth. Dosh moved to third base on a one-out double and Austin Wynns put Bowie ahead with a three-run homer to left center field. Gage (0-1) relinquished a double to the next batter and was replaced by Tyler Cyr. The lefty lasted 5 2/3 and allowed the three runs on seven hits. He struck out six and walked one in the loss.
Lucas Long found success in relief for Bowie and kept Richmond silent until the top of the seventh. T.J. Bennett drilled a doubleinto the left field corner and Rando Moreno delivered a two-out double up the first base line to trim the Bowie lead, 3-2. Long was able to strand Moreno at second to close out the inning. Long earned the win by scattering seven hits over 5 1/3 innings of work. He struck out three and did not walk a batter.
Richmond threatened to tie the game in the ninth when Tyler Horan roped a single to right field to open the inning. Closer Garrett Cleavinger then struck out two of the next three batters to end the game and earn the save.
Game two of the four game series is Tuesday night at 6:35 p.m. in Bowie, MD. Right right-hander Jordan Johnson is scheduled to start on Tuesday against TBD for Bowie. The Flying Squirrels return to The Diamond on Friday, April 21st against Reading. Season tickets, mini plans and group outings are available by contacting the Flying Squirrels box office at 804-359-3866 or online at www.squirrelsbaseball.com

...editor, and more. The Bowie Baysox edged out the Richmond Squirrels in a nail-biting series opener on Tuesday night, securing a 4-3 victory at Prince George's Stadium. The game was marked by a late-inning rally that saw the Baysox capitalize on a critical error by the Squirrels' defense.

Bowie's starting pitcher, Jake McCarthy, delivered a solid performance, striking out seven batters over six innings. However, it was the Baysox's offense that stole the show, with a standout performance from outfielder Marcus Lee, who went 3-for-4 at the plate, including a crucial two-run double in the seventh inning.

Richmond fought back valiantly, with a home run from first baseman Tom Reed that brought the Squirrels within one run in the ninth. Despite their efforts, Bowie‚Äôs closer, Alex Torres, held firm, securing the final out and sealing the win for the Baysox. The teams will face off again tomorrow night in what promises to be another thrilling matchup.

Manchester United's surge up the Premier League table continued with a victory over 10-man West Ham on Monday.
Given how much happened on the field, those watching could be forgiven for missing bits and pieces around the periphery.
But don't worry, Sportsmail was on hand to make sure everything that passed you by has been preserved for posterity in one tidy little bundle. It's our pleasure...
Juan Mata is approached by a Manchester United fan as he celebrates scoring at West Ham
Zlatan Ibrahimovic was also on the scoresheet for United in their 2-0 victory
MOURINHO vs HAMMERHEAD
After all the controversy of Harry the Hornet's dive at the feet of Wilfried Zaha, the mascots of the Premier League are under constant watch in the early days of 2017.
When West Ham's very own 'Hammerhead' - a cunning cross between a shark and a household tool - approached Jose Mourinho on his way to the United bench, therefore, all sorts of options were possible.
Would 'Hammerhead' run, arms aloft, along the touchline before powersliding like at 70s lead guitarist at the Portuguese's feet? Would he mock Mourinho with a series of put-me-downs based entirely on the latest Black & Decker range? Would he slap him round the head with a copy of the Wickes catalogue?
Sadly not. He barely flexed a muscle.
Hammerhead bottled it.
Jose Mourinho walks past the West Ham mascot 'Hammerhead' prior to kick-off
The United manager gave Hammerhead a brief tap on the shoulder as he walked past
NO COACH PROBLEMS
After their last experience of visiting West Ham, United's players could have been forgiven for donning suits of armour for their return trip.
But, unlike the scenes that greeted them ahead of the final game at Upton Park in May - when the team coach was treated like a bottle bank by fans who may or may not have been to the pub - a serene sight greeted Jose Mourinho and Co as they pulled into the London Stadium.
No baying mob, no bared teeth, not even a hint of a half-full Carlsberg 330ml fizzing through the back window.
In fact, there was barely a supporter of either persuasion in sight.
It would have helped that United managed to get to east London on time, which as we all know has become something of an issue in recent months.
Manchester United's team bus enjoyed an incident-free arrival at the London Stadium
It was a stark contrast to May, when the coach was pelted with bottles outside Upton Park
The United team bus pulls into the parking area at the London Stadium
BILIC AND THE BALET?
Managers often pull curious poses on the sidelines but rarely do you see a top coach exhibiting balletic grace in the process.
What a surprise it was, then, when Slaven Bilic executed a near-perfect first arabesque midway through the opening period at the London Stadium.
Sure, he's no Nureyev but does the big Croatian have a secret past in the Swan Lake troupe?
Slaven Bilic stands on one leg as he sends out instructions to his players
DE GEA'S MILESTONE
It seems ridiculous to think that, once upon a time, David de Gea's qualities as a goalkeeper in the Premier League sat beneath some pretty large question marks.
This appearance was the Spaniard's 250th appearance for United and, as ever, he was his side's Mr Reliable.
De Gea has come to the rescue more often than the Thunderbirds during his half-decade at Old Trafford and, even with his team playing against 10 men on Monday, he had to be alert throughout.
An early save from Dimitri Payet, another just before the break to deny Manuel Lanzini and then a superb stop from Michail Antonio gave United the foundation for a crucial win.
David de Gea made his 250th appearance for United in the game on Monday evening
THE HURDLING FAN
It's not that long ago that the greatest names in athletics were going for gold inside what is now West Ham's home, and the spirit of the Olympics returned on Monday as a United fan competed in his own version of the 110m hurdles.
Compelled to join his heroes on the pitch after Juan Mata put the visitors in front just after the hour mark, the unidentified supporter - dressed all in black - leapt clear of two flights of advertising hoardings to get onto the pitch, briefly celebrated with Mata and leapt back over the boards and into the stands.
The helpless/hapless stewards (delete as applicable) were left to aimlessly search for him in the away end.
A supporter made his way over two rows of advertising hoardings to celebrate with Juan Mata
The fan managed to get back into the away end without being collared by security
NOT A YELLOW?
High feet? Jumping in? Studs up? Out of control?
Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. I mean, let's face it, it looks like Cheikhou Kouyate is launching himself down the Jetstream Fast Flume at Butlin's.
Worth a booking?
Apparently not.
Welcome to Mike Dean's mind.
Chekihou Kouyate launched himself at both the ball and Henrikh Mkhitaryan
The West Ham midfielder appeared to be out of control as he tried to win possession
Mkhitaryan escaped without injury and Kouyate without a booking following the incident
MIKE DEAN AND TWITTER... AGAIN
You have to wonder whether Mr Dean is in fact powered by internet memes and if, after a hard afternoon's toil, he settles down on the sofa, plugs himself into his Safari browser and powers up on the latest batch of deprecating GIFs.
The official, who seems to be on a constant audition for his local am-dram's version of Othello, fed the online forums once again on Monday with his decision to dismiss Sofiane Feghouli for a late-but-not-particularly-reckless challenge on Phil Jones after 15 minutes.
It was the fastest red card in the Premier League this season and sparked a tried-and-tested backlash on social media.

...for missing the significance of the result. The match, held at Old Trafford, saw United dominate possession and create numerous chances, but it was a red card for West Ham's defender, which shifted the momentum decisively in favor of the home side. 

Bruno Fernandes opened the scoring with a well-placed penalty after a foul in the box, and shortly after, Marcus Rashford doubled the lead with a stunning strike from outside the area. West Ham struggled to cope with United's attacking prowess, and despite a spirited effort, they failed to find the back of the net.

As the match progressed, United's defense held firm, showcasing their improved organization under the new management. The victory not only boosts United's confidence but also solidifies their position in the top four, as they aim for Champions League qualification. Fans left the stadium buzzing, hopeful that this winning streak could signal a return to the club's former glory.

iPhone manufacturers' slowing sales are a bad omen for Apple
Photo: Michael Short, Bloomberg Image 1 of / 1 Caption Close Image 1 of 1 An Apple Inc. iPhone X smartphone is displayed during the sales launch at a store in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Friday, Nov. 3, 2017. An Apple Inc. iPhone X smartphone is displayed during the sales launch at a store in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Friday, Nov. 3, 2017. Photo: Michael Short, Bloomberg iPhone manufacturers' slowing sales are a bad omen for Apple 1 / 1 Back to Gallery
Investors hunting for clues to the iPhone X‚Äôs reception can take a deeper look at its main manufacturing partners. And the latest doesn‚Äôt look good.
Apple Inc.‚Äôs five largest device assemblers reported a sharp slowdown after peaking at the end of last year, suggesting demand for the high-end device may have faded just a quarter after its release.
While Hai Precision Industry Co., Pegatron Corp. and three other key suppliers reported an 8 percent rise in their total sales across the March quarter, growth cratered later in the period -- a drop that in the past has presaged a downturn for Apple.
The concern is that the iPhone X, while enjoying a customary holiday quarter spike for new-generation Apple gadgets, fizzled out rapidly. Apple‚Äôs costliest smartphone has struggled to draw customers in emerging markets, while competitors from Huawei to Xiaomi roll out more premium phones and dominate China -- the U.S. company‚Äôs biggest foreign market. On Friday, Morgan Stanley cut its estimate on iPhone shipments by 6 million, underscoring the growing unease since Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., the maker of iPhone processors, issued a disappointing outlook that triggered a 7 percent loss in Apple‚Äôs value over the past three days.
Recommended Video: Now Playing:
Upcoming: Apple might have a new iPhone SE in the works
Apple‚Äôs sales growth bears close correlation with that of its main quintet of assemblers, which depend on the iPhone maker for their own business growth -- Hon Hai alone gets about half its revenue from Cupertino. While it‚Äôs difficult to translate their numbers directly into Apple‚Äôs, a look at reported figures since 2016 suggests it‚Äôs possible to draw certain conclusions at the general health of the U.S. smartphone titan‚Äôs top-line.
The group is responsible for finishing most of Apple‚Äôs gizmos: Hon Hai, Pegatron and Wistron Corp. assemble iPhones. Hon Hai also has a role in other Apple products, splitting MacBooks with Quanta Computer Inc. and sharing iPads with Compal Electronics Inc. Quanta and Compal also make Apple Watches.
more techburger Get more tasty tech news at TechBurger. And follow us on Twitter and Facebook. Subscribe to the Chronicle for regular access to TechBurger stories and to be able to comment.
Hon Hai and crew can indeed offer insights into Apple‚Äôs sales but to a limited extent, said Jusy Hong, a director with IHS Markit. While Hon Hai, Quanta and Pegatron both rely on Cupertino for more than half their business, Wistron and Compal are far less dependent on Apple, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. In addition, as hardware mavens, their operations would have no impact on sales of software and services, a significant and growing part of Apple‚Äôs top and bottom line.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs true that they are major assemblers of Apple but at the same time they have other customers,‚Äù he said in an email.
Sour tune: Apple HomePod disappoints with slow sales
Investors remain concerned that iPhone sales at Apple, which reports results May 1, failed to meet their lofty expectations. Mia Huang, an analyst at Taipei-based research firm Trendforce, estimates that overall iPhone production volumes grew slightly to 54-56 million units in the March quarter -- barely up from 52 million in the same period of last year, when it was propelled by demand for lower-priced and older models like the iPhone 6S and ramp up of the iPhone 7.
‚ÄúAccording to our estimates, iPhone X‚Äôs production volume fell by 50% in the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter,‚Äù said Huang.
AMS AG -- which makes the optical sensors that control brightness and color -- became the latest Apple-supplier to cast doubt over the gadget‚Äôs reception. Its shares tumbled after warning on negative operating margins because of low production capacity at its Singapore factories, which Baader Helvea AG analyst Guenther Hollfelder said suggested lower iPhone X volumes than anticipated.
Still, the iPhone X‚Äôs higher price tag ensured a tidy jump in revenue. For now, analysts are still counting on the first three months this year to have been Apple‚Äôs best second quarter ever with an average estimate for $61 billion in revenue. And while its assembly quintet saw sales decelerate during the period, their collective growth is still double that of a year earlier.

...has been a flagship product for the company, but recent reports indicate that demand is waning. Analysts suggest that the saturation of the smartphone market, coupled with economic uncertainties, is leading to a decline in iPhone sales. This trend raises concerns about Apple's ability to maintain its revenue growth, as the iPhone accounts for a significant portion of the company's overall income.

In response to these challenges, Apple has been diversifying its product lineup and investing in services such as Apple Music and Apple TV+. However, the reliance on iPhone sales remains a critical factor for the company's financial health. Industry experts are closely monitoring the upcoming product launches and pricing strategies, as they could play a pivotal role in revitalizing interest in the iPhone. If sales continue to decline, it may prompt Apple to rethink its approach to innovation and market positioning in an increasingly competitive landscape.

MUMBAI: State Bank of India SBI ) has reduced its staff headcount by 6,622 in the first quarter of FY18 to 2.73 lakh from 2.80 lakh at the beginning of the quarter due to retirements and a voluntary retirement scheme . The bank now plans to redeploy over 10,000 employees following the merger of its associate banks and due to digitisation.Consolidation of associate banks and a shift to digital channels for banking have set in motion a job restructuring process in one of the largest employers in the country. "While the physics of the merger is over, the chemistry is yet to be completed," said Arundhati Bhattacharya , chairman, SBI, referring to the integration process after the merger of balance sheet which came into effect from the first quarter.A large part of the job restructuring is taking place on account of merger as the bank juggles its branch network to avoid having several outlets on the same street. SBI has merged 594 branches till August 6 and has rationalised 122 administrative offices. This in itself is expected to result in savings of over Rs 1,160 crore annually. The bank has entrusted a new entity‚ÄîSBI Infra Management‚Äîthe responsibility of managing its real estate assets.SBI is also finding the need to rationalise due to digitisation within and outside the bank. For instance, the bank is redeploying staff in government service branches as the Centre is shifting most of its banking operations to portals. Private lenders like HDFC Bank have been reducing their headcount at a much higher pace even as they push digital transaction. HDFC Bank's staff strength has come down from 90,421 in December 2016 to 84,325 in March 2017.In the first quarter of the current fiscal, the bank saw 7,247 employees exiting following retirements, including 3,569 employees of the erstwhile associate banks who were offered a voluntary retirement scheme. The bank had paid out Rs 473 crore ex gratia under this scheme which will result in salary savings of Rs 400 crore per annum. Of the staff redeployment planned by SBI, 2,000 will be because of shifting of administrative offices and another 8,618 due to branch rationalisation. Around 30% of the staff of rationalised branches will be redeployed in sales functions. The bank has introduced a new employee appraisal system where performers will receive financial incentives.The total employees of SBI and associates as on March 31 was around 2.80 lakh. The number has been stagnant for a couple of years as there has been a hump in retirements of large number of employees hired during the '80s. As against the exits, the bank has hired only 625 staff members in the first quarter, taking the total headcount down to 2,73,181. The number could further drop as full year retirements in FY18 are expected to be around 15,460. The bank is recruiting specialists for digital space and marketing though not in large numbers.The share of alternative (non-branch) channels in transactions has increased substantially from 76% a year ago to 80% on June 2017. The share of internet banking has increased from 24% to 30% of all transactions. Interestingly, ATM transactions are only 34% of transactions as against 43% a year ago.

...the fiscal year. This reduction is part of the bank's ongoing efforts to streamline operations and improve efficiency in a challenging economic environment. The decrease in workforce comes as SBI aims to leverage technology and digital banking solutions to enhance customer service and reduce operational costs.

The bank has been focusing on automation and digitalization, which has led to a shift in the skill sets required for its workforce. As a result, SBI is investing in training programs to upskill existing employees and prepare them for new roles in a more technology-driven banking landscape.

Despite the reduction in headcount, SBI reported a growth in its net profit for the quarter, driven by an increase in net interest income and a decline in bad loans. The bank remains optimistic about its future growth prospects, emphasizing its commitment to maintaining a strong balance sheet while adapting to the evolving banking sector.

with some praising the nostalgic revival of a beloved sport, while others criticized the production quality and pacing. Fans of the original World of Sport Wrestling, which aired from the 1960s to the 1980s, were excited to see familiar faces and classic wrestling styles, but some felt that the new format struggled to capture the essence of its predecessor.

The show featured a mix of established stars and up-and-coming talent, showcasing a variety of wrestling styles that appealed to both old-school fans and a new generation. However, the lack of a cohesive storyline and character development left some viewers wanting more. 

Despite the mixed reviews, the broadcast marked a significant moment for British wrestling, reigniting interest in the sport and prompting discussions about its future on television. Promoters and wrestlers alike are hopeful that this revival could lead to more regular programming and a resurgence of live events across the UK.

A Russian journalist who turned up alive and well less than 24 hours after he was reported murdered features on many of the front pages on Thursday.
Police had said on Tuesday that Arkady Babchenko had been shot and killed at his apartment building in Ukraine ‚Äì but the 41-year-old appeared at a news conference on Wednesday.
He announced that he had faked his own death in order to thwart a genuine plot by Moscow to kill him, The Guardian reports.
What the papers say - May 31
Guardian front page, Thursday 31 May 2018: I faked my own death to avoid Kremlin hitman, says journalist pic.twitter.com/uxnA6WlfgX ‚Äî The Guardian (@guardian) May 30, 2018
The i says the journalist ‚Äúshocked the world‚Äù when he turned up at the press conference about his own killing, and reports that there were gasps and cheering when he walked in.
He apologised to his wife and daughters who had been in mourning, the paper adds.
Both The Sun and the Daily Star run with the headline: ‚ÄúYou Only Live Twice‚Äù, with The Sun reporting that a Ukrainian MP claimed the faked assassination was based on a Sherlock Holmes plot.

...that Ivan Safronov, a prominent journalist and former military officer, had been found dead in his apartment, prompting widespread outrage and concern for press freedom in Russia. However, in a surprising twist, Safronov appeared at a press conference the following day, stating that he had been in hiding due to threats against his life. He claimed that the initial reports of his death were part of a disinformation campaign aimed at silencing dissenting voices in the media.

The incident has raised alarms among human rights organizations, which argue that the Russian government has increasingly targeted journalists and activists. Safronov, known for his investigative work on military corruption and state secrets, expressed his determination to continue his work despite the risks. "I will not be intimidated," he declared, calling for greater protections for journalists in Russia. The police have launched an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the false reports of his death, but many remain skeptical of their commitment to uncovering the truth.

evangelism, podcast
Episode Eighteen | Two Practical Ways to Show and Share the Love of Jesus with Others
Wes Holland, Program Administrator of the Rural Matters Institute at the Billy Graham Center, reminds us that God went on a rescue mission for us, and that we must do the same for others. He shares two challenges that will help us truly serve God. These two simple steps ‚Äì being present instead of just occupying space and writing down our gospel moments in order to share them with others ‚Äì can make all the difference in seeing those around us come to faith.
Episode Seventeen | When It Seems as Though God Is Up to Nothing
Laurie Nichols, Director of Communications at the Billy Graham Center, reminds us that even when we don‚Äôt see God working, He is. And if we remain faithful in prayer and seek ways to reach out to those who don‚Äôt yet know the love of God, He will open doors.
Stay the course, friends. Your work is not in vain (Heb. 6:10). Keep working as though it all depends on you (Col. 3:23), and keeping praying as though it all depends on God (Eph. 6:18).
Episode Sixteen | Are Our Gospel Conversations Only Empty Words?
Kerilee Van Schooten, Church Evangelism Research and Ministries Coordinator at the Billy Graham Center, reminds us that our evangelism must be authentic and real, or people will know it. When others sense we care for them, their hearts soften to the good news we are seeking to share. We must also be ready for how others will respond, even if it‚Äôs difficult to hear.
Episode Fifteen | How to Get Into a Gospel Conversation
Jerry Root, Evangelism Professor and Director of the Evangelism Initiative at the Billy Graham Center, discusses how we can get into gospel conversations easily and winsomely. These practical how-tos cover the desire to be loved by God and an understanding that we are all messed up. Talking to people about the love and forgiveness of God is natural and isn‚Äôt as hard as we think.
Episode Fourteen | Paying It Forward ‚Äì The Christian Way
Karen Swanson, Director of the Institute for Prison Ministries at the Billy Graham Center, talks about acts of kindness and how the concept of ‚Äòpaying it forward‚Äô can be used as part of our evangelism strategy. Our acts of service, when combined with our gospel proclamation, make a very powerful witness.
Episode Thirteen | Listening: The Beginning of Love
Christina Walker, Associate Director of Academic Programs at the Billy Graham Center, discusses Dietrich Bonhoeffer‚Äôs Life Together and the first service we owe to others. We must begin with listening to others. In the cacophony of noise, will we be the kind of people who will truly love others best by actually getting to know them? When we talk with non-Christians, our first step might just be closing our mouths.
Episode Twelve | Inconvenient Evangelism Moments
John Richards, Managing Director of the Billy Graham Center, discusses inconvenient evangelism moments and how we can begin to step into them in order to see God change lives. John uses personal examples to encourage us to actually pray for ‚Äòinconvenient‚Äô moments for the furtherance of the gospel and the potential of changed lives. We must remember that one moment can impact someone‚Äôs eternity.
Episode Eleven | Why Do Words Matter?
Ed Stetzer, Executive Director of the Billy Graham Center, discusses the intersection of showing AND sharing the love of Jesus. Why did Jesus come, and how do we hold in tension serving others and proclaiming Christ to others? The gospel isn‚Äôt something we do; it‚Äôs something Jesus did. How are we responding?

Ed Stetzer holds the Billy Graham Distinguished Chair of Church, Mission, and Evangelism at Wheaton College, is Executive Director of the Billy Graham Center, and publishes church leadership resources through Mission Group.

...Graham Evangelistic Association, discusses the importance of evangelism in today‚Äôs world. In this episode, he emphasizes two practical ways to demonstrate and share the love of Jesus with others.

First, Wes highlights the significance of building genuine relationships. He encourages listeners to engage with their communities, listen actively, and show compassion. By investing time in others, believers can create a safe space for conversations about faith. 

Second, he suggests utilizing social media as a tool for outreach. In a digital age, sharing personal testimonies, inspirational messages, and scripture can reach a wider audience. The National Junior Angus Association (NJAA) is beginning its search for the next Angus Ambassador. It‚Äôs an elite position that provides an opportunity for a one-year term as spokesperson for the NJAA‚Äôs nearly 6,000 members, and connects with cattle producers, consumers and industry professionals nationwide. Applications are available online and must be submitted by Sept. 15.
‚ÄúAs the Angus Ambassador, one junior member is given the opportunity to take his or her passion for Angus cattle to the next level by networking with other Angus producers and beef industry professionals, and by traveling to and attending a variety of engaging events over the course of the year,‚Äù says Jaclyn Clark, American Angus Association Director of Events and Education.
Currently serving as the 2017 Angus Ambassador is Cassandra Garcia of Renton, Washington. Garcia is a student at the University of Washington Tacoma studying business marketing. She says she hopes that one day her education in the area of business will allow her to contribute to the ‚ÄúBusiness Breed‚Äù in a meaningful way.
‚ÄúThe ambassador program has been a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity that has given me the chance to expand my understanding of this industry‚Äù, says Garcia. ‚ÄúWhether it was networking at events, being that bridge between consumers and producers, or representing the Angus breed in the best way possible, it has helped me to grow as an individual in an industry that I love.‚Äù
The chosen Angus Ambassador will travel to the following events:
Angus Convention in Fort Worth, Texas (candidates);
Certified Angus Beef ¬Æ Building Blocks Seminar in Wooster, Ohio;
Building Blocks Seminar in Wooster, Ohio; NCBA Cattle Industry Annual Convention in Phoenix, Arizona.;
Beef Improvement Federation Annual Research Symposium and Convention in Loveland, Colorado; and
Guiding Outstanding Angus Leaders (GOAL) Conference in Canada.
Additonal and existing travel may vary based on the selected ambassador‚Äôs location, schedule and availability.
To be eligible for the Angus Ambassador competition, applicants must be Association members in good standing, between the ages 17-20 as of Jan. 1, who own purebred Angus cattle. They must submit a cover letter, r√©sum√© and two essay responses. Applications can be found online.
Garcia encourages all junior members to apply for the position: ‚ÄúWe need strong leaders to represent our association. If you‚Äôre thinking about applying, go ahead and do it! I believe all NJAA members have what it takes to become the next great representative of our breed.‚Äù
All applications must be postmarked by Sept. 15 and sent to the Association‚Äôs Events and Education Department, 3201 Frederick Ave., Saint Joseph, MO 64506.
Once the applications are reviewed, five finalists will be invited to the Angus Convention to participate in the final round of competition, which includes an interview and formal presentation with a panel of judges. The new Angus Ambassador will be chosen at the Awards Recognition Breakfast on Nov. 6 .
For more information, please visit the NJAA website at www.angus.org/njaa.
About the National Junior Angus Association
The NJAA promotes the involvement of young people in raising Angus cattle, while also providing leadership and self-development opportunities for more than 6,000 active members nationwide.

the NJAA and the Angus breed. The Angus Ambassador will represent the association at various events, including state fairs, national conventions, and industry conferences, promoting the values and benefits of Angus cattle. Candidates must be NJAA members aged 16 to 21 and demonstrate strong communication skills, leadership qualities, and a passion for the beef industry.

Applications are now open and will be accepted until March 15. Interested individuals are encouraged to submit a written application, along with a video introduction showcasing their personality and commitment to the Angus breed. Finalists will be interviewed by a panel of judges during the NJAA's annual conference in June, where the new ambassador will be announced.

This role not only enhances the ambassador's public speaking and networking skills but also provides invaluable experiences that can shape their future careers in agriculture. The NJAA looks forward to welcoming a new representative who will inspire and engage the next generation of Angus enthusiasts.

NEW YORK The U.S. stock market rallied sharply in the wake of President Donald Trump's election on Nov. 8, fueled by the hopes for his agenda of cutting taxes, spending on infrastructure and reducing regulations.
But since he took office, the road toward enacting these proposals has proved bumpy, and several of the early stock winners have faded.
Here is a look at four "Trump trades" and how they have fared since his election and since his inauguration.
OBAMACARE
Barometer: Index of five hospital stocks (HCA Holdings (HCA.N), Tenet Healthcare (THC.N), Universal Health Services (UHS.N), Community Health Systems (CYH.N), LifePoint Health (LPNT.O))
Election to inauguration: -7.1 percent
Inauguration to present: +4.1 percent
President Trump's election sent shivers through investors in hospital operators because of his vow to immediately repeal the Affordable Care Act, known as Obamacare, which benefited hospitals by expanding insurance coverage.
But passing healthcare legislation has proved to be not so straightforward even though Trump's fellow Republicans control both chambers of Congress - which has helped the stocks recover. Republicans in the House of Representatives had to pull their first attempt at a bill in late March in a surprising setback for Trump.
The effort seemed to gain fresh momentum on Wednesday as a reworked version won key support from the conservative House Freedom Caucus, with hospital stocks falling after the news, but congressional aides said Thursday that House leaders decided against holding a vote on the healthcare overhaul this week.
INFRASTRUCTURE
Barometer: Index of six infrastructure-related stocks (Caterpillar (CAT.N), Terex (TEX.N), Vulcan Materials (VMC.N), AECOM (ACM.N), Granite Construction (GVA.N), Nucor (NUE.N))
Election to inauguration: +13 percent
Inauguration to present: +2.4 percent
Trump's vow to spend $1 trillion on infrastructure helped lead to a windfall for many investors in industries such as construction, engineering, building materials and steel in the immediate aftermath of the election.
Trump has maintained strong support for an infrastructure package, including earlier this month saying his overhaul could top $1 trillion on roads, tunnels and bridges, while promising to cut red tape to speed approval of infrastructure projects. But performance of the stocks has leveled off as an infrastructure package has not yet materialized, while there are indications that putting such a massive program to work could be easier said than done.
BANKS
Barometer: S&P 500 banks index .SPXBK
Election to inauguration: +20.8 percent
Inauguration to present: +3.1 percent
Perhaps no sector benefited as much from President Trump's election as banking in the immediate aftermath of his win. Optimism over his ability to roll back regulations boosted the group. Expectations that his agenda would stimulate the economy, promoting inflation and higher interest rates, also energized investors in banking stocks.
But after the stocks' big run, concerns about slowing loan growth have emerged for banks. Trump has pledged to roll back regulations and reforms put in place after the 2008 financial crisis, but his struggle so far in Congress left doubts about whether he can push through such deregulation.
Even though former Goldman Sachs executives populate his administration, Trump himself has been a bit of a wild card for banks, including recent comments that he would like to see interest rates stay low.
TAX CUTS
Barometer: Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks
Election to inauguration: +12.6 percent
Inauguration to present: +5.3 percent
Trump's plan to cut taxes broadly and reform the tax code gave investors reason to be optimistic about U.S. equities after his election, particularly investing in smaller companies that tend to be more domestically focused.
The promise of tax cuts is still driving the market, which has surged to near records in recent days as Trump was primed to propose slashing the corporate income tax rate to 15 percent. But Trump's struggle in his first legislative effort - repealing Obamacare - has sowed doubts about his ability to enact his plans.
Since Trump started in office, investors have also expressed concerns that his involvement in international issues in Syria, North Korea and elsewhere would distract from his domestic agenda.
(Reporting by Lewis Krauskopf; Editing by Nick Zieminski)

and deregulation. Investors were optimistic that Trump's policies would stimulate economic growth and lead to higher corporate profits. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged over 1,000 points in the days following the election, marking one of the most significant post-election rallies in history.

Financial and industrial stocks led the charge, with banks benefiting from expectations of higher interest rates and reduced regulations. Additionally, the energy sector saw gains as Trump‚Äôs administration signaled support for fossil fuel production and infrastructure projects. 

However, analysts cautioned that the market's rapid ascent could lead to volatility, especially if Trump's policies faced significant hurdles in Congress. Concerns over trade policies and potential geopolitical tensions also loomed, prompting some investors to remain cautious. As the transition period unfolded, market participants closely monitored cabinet appointments and legislative proposals, eager to gauge the potential impact on the economy and stock market trajectory in the months ahead.

LIMERICK U-21 hurling manager Pat Donnelly and selectors Brian Foley, Maurice O‚ÄôBrien and Mikey Kiely have released a 26-man for Saturday‚Äôs All Ireland U-21 hurling semi final.
The starting 15 will be confirmed on Thursday evening.
Seamus Flanagan and Josh Adams are additions to the 24 players that were togged out for the Munster final win over Cork. Flanagan is yet to get game-time this season but is one of 14 members of the Limerick panel that hold an All Ireland U-21 medal from 2015.
Limerick, who are 4/5 favourites for the All Ireland title, have used 23 different players in their three games to-date.
The star-studded Limerick panel are Thurles bound for the All Ireland semi final meeting with Galway. The game in Semple Stadium has a 6.00 start, while Kilkenny play Derry in the other semi final at 4.00 ‚Äì both live on TG4.
While Limerick have beaten Tipperary, Clare and Cork enroute to winning the Munster title, Saturday will be Galway‚Äôs first U-21 game of the season.
But Galway hurling is riding a crest of a wave at present with their senior and minor teams already into September 3 All Ireland finals.
The Tribesmen U-21s are managed by Tony Ward. Star forward Conor Whelan is the only member of their senior team eligible for the U-21 grade but others like Sean Loftus, Thomas Monaghan and Jack Grealish are senior substitutes. Limerick can call upon seven players that played senior inter-county championship this Summer.
Three years ago at minor level, Limerick were 1-27 to 2-9 winners over Galway in the All Ireland MHC semi final and the bookies make the Shannonsiders the 1/6 favourites to repeat that victory and reach the September 9 final in Thurles. Galway did however win the All Ireland minor title in 2015.
Saturday will be the eighth meeting of Limerick and Galway at U-21 level ‚Äì Limerick have five victories, including the last meeting in 2015. Six of that Limerick team will most likely once again start ‚Äì Sean Finn, Ronan Lynch, Cian Lynch, Colin Ryan, Barry Nash and captain Tom Morrissey.
PANEL: Josh Adams (Ballybrown), Paudie Ahern (Killeedy), Conor Boylan (Na Piarsaigh), Peter Casey (Na Piarsaigh), Andrew La Touche Cosgrave (Monaleen), Daragh Fanning (Pallasgreen), Sean Finn (Bruff), Seamus Flanagan (Feohanagh), Aaron Gillane (Patrickswell), Thomas Grimes (Na Piarsaigh), Robbie Hanley (Kilmallock), Kyle Hayes (Kildimo-Pallaskenry), Cian Hedderman (Ballybrown), Dan Joy (Kilmallock), Lorcan Lyons (Monaleen), Cian Lynch (Patrickswell), Ronan Lynch (Na Piarsaigh), Mike Mackey (Adare), Eoghan McNamara (Doon), Conor McSweeney (South Liberties), Tom Morrissey (Ahane), Barry Murphy (Doon), Barry Nash (South Liberties), Jack O‚ÄôGrady (Knockainey), Oisin O‚ÄôReilly (Kilmallock), Colin Ryan (Pallasgreen).

...features a blend of experienced players and promising young talent, showcasing the depth of Limerick's hurling program. Key players to watch include captain and midfielder John O‚ÄôNeill, whose leadership on the field has been instrumental throughout the campaign. The forward line is bolstered by the dynamic duo of Liam O‚ÄôConnor and Sean O‚ÄôLeary, both of whom have been in fine scoring form.

In defense, the team will rely on the solid performances of full-back Tom√°s O‚ÄôReilly, who has consistently thwarted opposing attacks.
